PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Disarmament
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:
Nuclear Disarmament
To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That your petitioners are concerned about foreign owned military bases on Australian territory and the entry into Australian waters and territory of foreign warships and aircraft carrying nuclear weaponry. And that the Australian Government should take an active and constructive role in the promotion of a nuclear-free world. Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should:
1. Promote the expression of Australian sovereignty by legislation to bring foreign military bases on Australian territory under the control of the Australian Government.

2. Make it compulsory that the disclosure of weaponry carried by foreign warships and aircraft be given in confidence to the Australian Government prior to a request for entry. And that foreign warships and aircraft that carry nuclear weaponry be banned from Australian waters and territory.
3. Legislate for the cessation of all uranium mining in Australia and its subsequent export.

4. Urge the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to pose to the Governments of the United States and the Soviet Union that both countries agree to immediately half the testing, production and further deployment of all nuclear weapons, missiles and delivery systems in a way that can be checked and verified by both sides.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Macklin (from 143 citizens) and Scott (from 139 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Act
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of certain elected representatives and officers of local governments in Australia shows that:
General revenue grants to local government under personal income tax sharing entitlements have increased by 8.2 per cent in 1983-84 over 1982-83,
The inflation rate over the same period was 11.2 per cent,
The increase in grants to State Governments over the same period was 11.8 per cent,
Increased demands are being made on local government authorities to participate in Federal Government programs e.g. Community Employment Program,
The Labor Party made a pre-election commitment to allocate not less than the real value of the previous year's allocation in general revenue grants to local government.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Government will amend the Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Act of 1976, to provide a real term minimum guarantee to local government general revenue sharing arrangements in 1983-84, and in future years.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Lewis (from 13 citizens) and Scott (from 38 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:
That, with the exception of the Northern Territory, all State Parliaments have enacted chiropractic legislation.
That chiropractors provide a safe, effective and economical health care service that is complementary to medicine.

That the introduction of a Federally funded health care system restricted to the services provided almost exclusively by the medical profession restricts the freedom to select the health care practitioner of one's choice.
That a financial disadvantage will be incurred by those citizens utilising chiropractic care, many of whom find that their health complaints do not respond satisfactorily to traditional approaches.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled ensures that chiropractic services are included in Medicare when it is introduced.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:
That, with the exception of the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory, all State Parliaments have enacted chiropractic legislation.
That chiropractors provide a safe, effective and economical health care service that is complementary to medicine.

That the introduction of a Federally funded health care system restricted to the services provided almost exclusively by the medical profession restricts the freedom to select the health care practitioner of one's choice.
That a financial disadvantage will be incurred by those citizens utilising chiropractic care, many of whom find that their health complaints do not respond satisfactorily to traditional approaches.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled ensures that chiropractic services are included in Medicare when it is introduced.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
That the Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 contains provisions inconsistent with principles of justice and equality which could be used to:
Undermine civil liberties and religious freedoms;
Entrench abortion funding and render liable to action hospitals, doctors and nurses, who conscientiously refuse to become involved in morally objectionable operations;
Deny to parents their rights to insist that the school 'community' provide an environment conducive to the development, including moral development of their children.

Your petitioners humbly pray the the Senate, in Parliament assembled; should amend the Bill so as to prevent the possibility of its use in the manner stated above and urge, because of the importance to society of all principles involved, that a conscience vote on the Bill be permitted to all members of Parliament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Drugs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we support your efforts to strengthen our family and community life particularly by increased penalties for 'drug pushers' and distributors. We, however, wish to register our firm opposition to any legal changes which would increase or encourage the distribution or availability of so-called 'soft drugs' such as marijuana. We believe such drugs to be harmful to the physical and psychological health of the individual and therefore to the interest of the community of which such individual is part. Although there is current controversy concerning the question of such harm it appears to us quite foolish to legalise and encourage the use of such drugs unless or until it be shown that such drugs are in fact harmless. The serious social problems of alcohol should provide sufficient warning to our society.
Any efforts to legalise or decriminalise usage or distribution of such drugs will have the following results:
1. Encourage and inculcate a social acceptability towards such drugs.
2. Increase the volume of usage of such drugs in schools and the community by present users and by ''drug pushers'' through the proposed one oz. legal possession.
3. Extend the usage of such drugs to persons who would previously have abstained because of the legal sanctions.

4. Put pressure upon Parliament to establish and licence import, growth, manufacture and/or distribution of such drugs, that is, to regulate another destructive industry contrary to the best interest of the individual and society .
5. There would be the probable temptation to tax such drugs as another source of Federal revenue.

We urge the Government to increase the medical and counselling facilities for the assistance of drug users and to expand existing drug referral centres and clinics. We have general confidence in the existing law and its sympathetic implementation by the Police and Courts. Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your honourable House will firstly take no measures that could extend the major social problem of drug usage and secondly will oblige those who are promoting marijuana and/or similar drugs to prove without doubt that such drugs are harmless before any legislation or decriminalisation of use is introduced.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
We have become the innocent victims of your Government's Medicare scheme.
We are forced to pay 1 per cent of our wages only to receive less per capita benefits than the people of other states.

Without canvassing the rights or wrongs of the dispute between the Federal Government and the State of Queensland the fact is that because of it over one million Queenslanders, who contribute to health funds, are being blatantly discriminated against compared with people in the rest of Australia.
Because of the dispute over the introduction of Medicare, Queensland public hospital bed charges are $120 per day compared with $80.00 per day in the other states. This is grossly unfair.
As it was the Federal Government which decided to introduce Medicare, we believe it is their responsibility to take action allowing health funds' rates in Queensland to be kept at reasonable levels.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, should use its influence with Government so as to avoid the discrimination (of $ 40 per day) against insured Queenslanders.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Education
PETITION.PARA: To the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the State of Victoria showeth that any reduction in Government funding of non-Government schools would seriously affect the quality of the educational services provided and cause financial hardship for many parents.

Your petitioners therefore pray that any change in the funding system for non- Government schools recognises the fundamental right of all children to an equitable share of Government funds for education.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Peter Baume (from seven citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Environmental Protection
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

But for a High Court decision narrowly favouring the Federal Government, recently discovered 20,000 years old archaeological cave sites near the Franklin River, Tasmania, equal in importance to those in the V'ese`re Valley in France, would have been destroyed, like a United Kingdom Government unable to stop a Wiltshire authority from clearing Stonehenge for a freeway. The constitutional basis for protecting historical and environmental assets remains weak.
Your petitioners therefore most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should request the Government to hold a referendum to amend the constitution so that:

The Federal Government has the duty and a right superior to state and local governments to set above the commercial advantage of one generation, protect and restore, those things we hold in trust for the future;
Being relics, sites, features, areas, wildlife, buildings or things of Aboriginal and other historical, cultural, scientific, aesthetic, ecological or environmental importance;
To care for the maintenance of the balance of nature, to manage land, marine and atmospheric use so as to avoid their degradation and in any other matter which might be seen to be in the same spirit;
In particular to prevent beach mining, preserve the Heritage Areas, The Great Barrier Reef Region at least as originally defined in the 1975 Act and consider its extension into the Torres Strait.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition from parents representing the government schools in New South Wales respectfully showeth that:
1. They call on the Federal Government to re-affirm publicly that its primary obligation is to government schools.
2. They support the Federal Government's policy decisions which have reduced funding to wealthy private schools and which have broken the nexus between government and non-government school costs.
3. They endorse the Federal Government's opposition to the provision of a 'base grant' to all non-government schools.
4. They ask that the Federal Government create a general recurrent resource base which is adequate for government schools through the provision of increased recurrent funding.

5. They call upon the Federal Government to negotiate agreements with State/ Territory Governments which will ensure a planned program of improvements in government schools throughout the coming decade.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Great Barrier Reef Marine Park
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That the Great Barrier Reef is unique and is included on the World Heritage List.

Although the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act was to create a marine park to provide for the proper protection and management of the Reef, only 14 per cent of the total area defined in this Act as the Great Barrier Reef Region has been declared marine park.
The only insurance against an oil drilling blowout in Reef waters is to prohibit oil drilling in the Region and its vicinity.
This can only be effected by declaring the whole area of the Region a marine park under the above legislation.

Your petitioners therefore most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should request the Government to take action to hold a referendum together with the next Federal Elections on the question that: 'The entire area of the Great Barrier Reef and its surrounding waters, defined as the Great Barrier Reef Region in the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act 1975, as amended 1978, be immediately declared a marine park under the provisions of that Act.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Friendly Societies
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

We the undersigned, being electors in the State of NSW, respectfully submit that the Government review its intention to tax Friendly Societies after so many years of service to the community at large.
And in faith your petitioners will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
We the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth do humbly pray that the Commonwealth government:

1. Uphold the principle that the seeds and cuttings of plants are a public resource and a common heritage to all and that accordingly seeds should be freely available to all, freely multipliable, able to be sold, exchanged, exported and imported by anyone who wishes. This is seen as a matter of national food security.

2. Recognize that plant breeding is a highly co-operative venture often involving private enterprise at the very last stages after basic seed collection , storage, and research has been publicly funded.
3. In view of the aforementioned paragraphs, recognise that any system giving ' property' or ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises is inappropriate and unjust.
4. Recognise that legislation establishing plant patenting schemes overseas has had serious adverse effects namely:
(i) a slowing-down of scientific information exchange and exchanges in basic plant breeding materials, that is, germ plasm,
(ii) subordination and/or curtailment of public breeding programmes,
(iii) farmer unrest at seed prices,
(iv) monopoly control of seed production and sales has passed into the hands of giant petrochemical and drug corporations also marketing crop chemicals,
(v) increased uniformity of crop varieties leading to a vulnerability to pest and disease attack.
5. Reject any proposal to legislate for any system such as the drafted Plant Variety Rights Act, which gives exclusive ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sub-Post Office: Doncaster
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

The policies of Australia Post within the Ministry for Communications are discriminating against small business in that most suitable and well patronised small shops are being denied the opportunity to operate as its sub-agents.
This discrimination is in contravention of, or contrary to, the spirit of the Trade Practices Act.
We respectfully request that a sub-Post Office be restored to its original historical site since the 1860's: the newsagency in the Central Court Shopping Centre, Doncaster Road, Doncaster.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Lithuanian Language
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Senators of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

(1) That it was announced in May 1982 that the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission is to provide $2.7 million over the next three years to institutions in all mainland states and the ACT to specially fund the study of certain modern foreign languages.
(2) That the study of the Lithuanian language was excluded from the said allocation.

(3) That the Lithuanian Community in Australia was led to believe that Lithuanian would be taught at at least one Australian university as a result of the findings of the review of multicultural and migrant education published by the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs in September 1980.

(4) That Lithuanian is taught at secondary level in Victoria, New South Wales and South Australia and apart from its relevance to the present Lithuanian Community is an extremely significant language in linguistic theory.
(5) That Monash University in Victoria already has a teaching staff suitable for incorporation of a Lithuanian language Department and already provides a course in Slavic and Baltic studies.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government will make an immediate appropriation of funds to ensure the study of the Lithuanian language at one of the Australian universities, preferably Monash.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Attorney-General whether he recalls telling me on 7 March, in relation to the Sala case:

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.

8th March, 1984.
Senator G. Evans, Esq.,
Attorney-General,
Parliament House,
Canberra, A.C.T. 2600
Dear Senator Evans,
Re: Ramon Llul Sala: Issues Currently Under Examination.

As your enquiries will confirm, I am a former Commonwealth Police Officer and I was one of the arresting officers of the abovenamed person in 1974. I have already been interviewed by Mr Andrew Menzies in relation to this matter and I understand that his report has already been submitted to you.

During the course of my discussions with Mr Menzies, I pointed out my reluctance to become involved in the current political morass, especially when the behaviour of many of the Parliamentary members seems to leave so much to desire. I am nearing the completion of my studies to gain my degree of Bachelor of Laws and I conduct my own business, which is currently enjoying a period of rapid growth. I therefore have no wish to be distracted by the antics of politicians over something that happened so long ago, even though the issues involved had a marked impact on my life.

What has prompted me to write, however, is the report on the front page of the Sydney Morning Herald of this date in which you are reported to have said, inter alia, that ''the police had the passport for six weeks, but had not been prepared to lay a charge-which they could have done at any time when they had a reasonable suspicion that the law had been broken.'' Mr Menzies was made quite aware of the fact that we, as investigating Police, had sought to lay charges against Mr Sala in relation to his false Passport almost immediately after the offence was detected, but we had been prevented from doing so, because the deportation order had been signed. As you should be aware, the permission of an authorized officer was required before a charge could be laid under the Migration Act in respect of the offence and we were not able to obtain such permission because of the existence of the deportation order. We were also informed that any possible charge under other statutes would not be entertained by your Department.

I also made it quite clear to Mr Menzies that the passport itself was quite obviously false upon inspection and, in itself, formed prima facie evidence of the offence. Had we been permitted to charge Mr Sala in relation to the matter, I am confident a magistrate would have remanded Mr Sala until our investigations could be completed, especially as his identity was supported only by the patently false document.

There are a great many issues associated with the Sala matter, including offers of bribes; the exertion of pressure by the naming of senior police officers; administrative inaction; political and interdepartmental interference; etc. I, like so many people, have come to accept corruption and ineptitude as a fact of life and I no longer take any particular notice of it, unless it affects me or my family. As I also explained to Mr Menzies, I have no particular axe to grind in the current issue and I said that I don't envy the job of any one who would be given the task of ''playing down'' or explaining the events surrounding the person tentatively identified as Mr Ramon Sala.

Your reported comments have caused me considerable agitation, however, as they are suggestive of a failure on the part of the investigating police to follow through on the enquiry. This, as you should be aware, is far from the truth and, since many of those involved in the matter at my level are still employed by the Commonwealth and subject to disciplinary action for speaking out publicly, I feel a certain amount of duty to bring these matters to your attention.

Basically, I don't particularly care how the various parties extract themselves from the quagmire in which they so proudly strode ten years ago, but I will not have them do so at the expense of those of us that tried so hard to do the right thing. As I said to Mr Menzies, if the government wishes to write the issues off , they had better not ask those of us at my level of the enquiry for a public opinion on the matter. I'm afraid the statements that would be forthcoming would not auger well for any ''whitewash''.
Yours faithfully,
T. P. BOYLE
C.C. The Hon. Robert J. Hawke,
Prime Minister of Australia,
Parliament House,
Canberra, A.C.T.
The Hon. Andrew Peacock,
Leader of the Opposition,
Parliament House,
Canberra, A.C.T.
Senator the Hon. Gareth Evans Attorney-General Parliament House Canberra A.C.T. 2600 15 March 1984 M/84/2327:ACCM
Mr T. P. Boyle,PO Box 154,Bexley, N.S.W. 2207
Dear Mr Boyle,

Thank you for your letter of 8 March 1984 in which you refer to a report in the ''Sydney Morning Herald'' of that date of statements said to have been made by me in the Senate in relation to the case of Mr Ramon Sala. You were one of the investigating police officers in that case and you recently furnished information to Mr A. C. C. Menzies, a former senior officer of my Department whom I asked to furnish a report on that case.

You state in your letter that the investigating police were anxious to lay charges against Mr Sala in relation to this false passport but the permission of an authorised officer required under the Migration Act was withheld. You are concerned as to any suggestion that the police were not prepared to lay such a charge.

The words that ''the police had . . . not been prepared to lay a charge'' are the words of the Sydney Morning Herald, not mine. What I intended to convey to the Senate on 7 March was that, had there been grounds for suspicion sufficient to lay a charge, there would have been ample time for that suspicion to be checked out and decisions taken thereon. The time available was at least from the time of the person's arrest on 28 April. From the then Attorney-General's viewpoint, the facts were that there had been ample time to investigate and lay a charge and, for whatever the reason, no charge had been laid.

However, I was not to be taken to be implying any criticism of the police role in this case. I understand that the police supported a proposal by a prosecuting officer made at the time of Sala's committal proceedings that a charge be brought under section 27 of the Migration Act in respect of the passport but, as you point out, a decision was made by the Department of Immigration not to prosecute. Its consent to a prosecution was necessary.

Mr Menzies' report to me indicates that the basis for the proposal for prosecution of Sala, as communicated to the Central Office of the Department of Immigration, was that it was feared that Sala might be remanded and released on bail but, if he were dealt with on the section 27 charge on a plea of guilty as anticipated, his release would be deferred. The Police and the Prosecutor had in mind that, the longer Sala's release was deferred, the greater the chance that he would disclose his confederates.

Mr Menzies' report shows that the decision of the Immigration Central Office was that, as a deportation order had been signed, they could not agree to a section 27 prosecution merely as a precaution against bail. The Central Office noted that the Court could be informed that the Minister had ordered deportation and that this would be effective when court action was complete.

Mr Menzies concluded, and I would agree, that this decision was by no means unreasonable. However, it appears from the records of the Sydney Deputy Crown Solicitor and the Sydney Office of the Department of Immigration, that the decision was understood in Sydney to be that, merely because there was a deportation order, there could not be a prosecution; this of course, is not correct in law.

Mr Menzies' report thus concludes that suspicion of the decision appeared to have arisen from a misunderstanding of the real basis for it and, when all the facts were known, the decision was not open to serious criticism. In any event, there was not the slightest evidence that either the then Attorney-General or the Central Office of his Department was involved in the decision.
I trust that this explanation will remove the concern that you have expressed.
Yours sincerely,
GARETH EVANS
c.c. The Hon. R. J. L. Hawke, A.C., M.P.,
Prime Minister
The Hon. A. S. Peacock, M.P.,
Leader of the Opposition

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been some misunderstanding of the position as I explained it on 7 March. What I intended to convey to the Senate, as indeed I said in my reply to Mr Boyle, was that had there been grounds for suspicion sufficient to lay a charge there would have been ample time for that suspicion to be checked out and decisions to be taken thereon. The time available was at least from the time of the person's arrest on 28 April, and that is something between four and five weeks, to the time that Mr Sala actually left the country. From the then Attorney-General's viewpoint the facts were that there had been ample time to investigate and lay a charge and, for whatever the reason, no charge had been laid.

ANSWER.PARA: It now appears clear to me, although I was perhaps less than clear in articulating this at various early stages in the barrage of questions I received on the Sala case, that certainly the police were anxious to lay a charge, although it remains a matter for argument to this day as to whether, before the arrival of the Interpol confirmation of the falsity of the passport, the evidence then available to the police would have been such as to sustain a charge had that been the only evidence before the court. There is a genuine difference of opinion possible about that.

The particular reason why a charge was not laid was not in any way the fault of the police and certainly not the fault of Mr Boyle who seems to have been as assiduous then as he is now in endeavouring to bring the matter to some kind of judgment. Certainly, the police immediately charged with the task of investigating the matter were of the view that a charge ought to be laid and communicated that fact to the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs in Sydney. The Immigration Department in Sydney in turn communicated the request for consent to prosecute, because such a consent was required and still is required under the Migration Act, to the Immigration Department central office.

It appears that the difficulty-I have explained all this again in a letter to Mr Boyle-arose in the content of that communication because the proposal to prosecute on the passport charge, as it was communicated from the Immigration Department office in Sydney to the central office in Canberra, was based on a desire to ensure that Sala stayed in custody following the conclusion of the original committal proceedings in the hope that by being kept in custody he would disclose his confederates. The actual decision that was made by the Immigration Department in Canberra not to consent to a prosecution was based, in turn, on the belief-I believe it was a quite reasonable belief-that it could not agree to a prosecution on the passport charge merely as a precaution against bail being granted. When, in turn, it communicated that decision back to the Immigration Department in Sydney there was a further misunderstanding because the Immigration Department in Sydney believed that the decision that had been made in Canberra was that, simply because a deportation order had been made, it was not possible in law, for that reason, for a charge to be made under section 27 in relation to the false passport which was, of course, a very considerable simplification of the facts.

The reality of the matter is that everybody seems to have acted in good faith throughout at the police and Immigration Department levels. But there was a series of misunderstandings at these levels which produced a situation of no charge being laid. On any view of the matter, this all occurred at the police and departmental levels and did not, on any view of the facts as they are available to us, looking backwards, in any way involve the Attorney-General of the day whose own decisions came rather later in the piece. The net result of all that and the nub of Mr Boyle's allegations really reduce to the answer that I gave him. There may have been some misunderstandings. There was certainly no lack of diligence on the part of police officers concerned but there was no impropriety by anyone in the course of the decision that was then followed.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. In view of the clear evidence that the police, from the outset, suspected that the passport was forged, that this suspicion was backed up by the French Consul- General who believed it was forged and that the then Attorney-General knew of this, why did the Attorney-General not simply withhold the passport? I am not suggesting that the Attorney-General should have kept that person incarcerated. I direct my question specifically to the reason why the Attorney-General, in the knowledge that there was a strong suspicion and in the knowledge that Interpol had been asked whether the passport was forged, did not wait for Interpol by simply withholding the passport while leaving the person free in this country.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have indicated previously the circumstances of that decision. I suggest that this question is not so much a supplementary one as a wholly new question. The answer, in short, to track back over familiar territory , is that there was a deportation order outstanding against the person which implied the continuation of that person in custody until the deportation order was executed. It certainly was not within the capacity, as I understand it, of the then Attorney-General to order his release into the community at large given the currency of a deportation order still outstanding against him. I may be wrong about that. I will check it. It is not my belief that he had any such power. The only power the then Attorney-General had was either to order his release from gaol and order that he may be deported or alternatively to ensure that he would be released from gaol and forthwith dispatched from the country, not by way of deportation but carrying his own passport.

ANSWER.PARA: I have said that the reasons why he was given back his passport at that stage rather than being simply deported-the representations from the solicitor were, as they survive on the record, solely to the effect that the person should be deported- have to do, it would appear, first with administrative reasons and the difficulty that was being experienced in getting the appropriate bit of paper to enable the person to be deported to Spain; secondly, the fact that very much in everybody's mind by that stage was the consideration that the person claimed, apparently on a credible basis, to have been something of a political exile from Franco's Spain and that there were very real consequences associated with his being returned to there; and, thirdly, the consideration that, as Senator Sir John Carrick should be well aware, it is not at all uncommon for people subject to a deportation order to be allowed to leave the country, if they are prepared to pay their own fares and leave immediately, if there is no overwhelming reason for them to be deported as such. In the absence of overwhelming evidence as to the falsity of the passport the third consideration no doubt applied.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health and refers to a Press report quoting the South Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry economist as saying:

QUESTION.PARA: Doctors could wreck the Hawke Government's economic strategy if they dug their heels in over Medicare.

Does the Minister see this as a significant statement, coming as it does from a major employer organisation? Does the Minister believe that actions by some sections of the medical profession could threaten Australia's overall economic recovery by threatening the prices and incomes accord?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I read the article referred to by Senator Maguire. Although I think that some of the projected outcomes of the doctors dispute were a bit exaggerated in the article, I am pleased at least to see that one member of the business establishment and one important business organisation recognises the importance of Medicare and its advantages to the Australian people and the Australian economic situation. It is terribly important that we all remember that one of the key planks of the Australian Labor Party's policy before the last election was the introduction of a universal health insurance scheme. That scheme has been introduced. It is fair. It has been developed by the Party and was approved by the people of this country at the last election. Those doctors who are acting in an irresponsible way, as some of them are at the moment, are acting against the wishes of the people of this country.

ANSWER.PARA: The important matter which was raised in the article was the recognition by the business organisation and its economists that Medicare, the universal health insurance scheme, is an important part of the prices and incomes accord. I do not think anyone in this country believes that the accord is not essential if we are to continue the economic recovery that we have. It is worth while quoting clause 48 of the National Economic Summit Conference communique, which also drew attention to the importance of the health policies of this Government. It stated :

The Summit notes the announced health policies of the Government and believes that it is imperative that at the Commonwealth level a stable system should be introduced as a matter of urgency. The unions reaffirm their commitment that they will accept an offset in wage increases on account of the health insurance scheme.

The Chamber of Commerce overstates the issue a bit if it regards Medicare as being of importance to this country only because of its economic benefits to the whole country. The scheme is important to the whole community because under any other scheme large numbers of people are not covered by health insurance and do not have adequate health cover. It is important that this scheme continue to operate with the acceptance not only of the patients but also of the doctors. It is a great pity, I believe, that those doctors who are acting in an irresponsible way by refusing to accept that there must be some restrictions on their capacity to operate in publicly funded hospitals, using publicly funded facilities, do not accept that there has to be some restrictions if the taxpayer is to provide for their livelihood in this way. As Senator Maguire said, it is an important article; it is an important recognition by an important business organisation that health insurance is an important part of the social wage. It is of great importance in maintaining the accord and, therefore, of great importance in maintaining the economic progress which this country undoubtedly has made.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Attorney-General again to the letter which former police officer Boyle wrote to him on 8 March in which he rejected the Attorney- General's claim in Parliament on 7 March that police had not sufficiently advanced their investigation of Mr Ramon Sala's passport to justify charges being made. I ask: In the Attorney's defence of the actions of the then Attorney -General, Senator Murphy, has he relied heavily on the false claim which has now been exposed by Mr Boyle? If not, why did the then Attorney-General not take steps to fully acquaint himself with the police view before ordering Mr Sala's release? Finally, does he now agree, in the light of the new evidence, that the Attorney-General of the day erred in his decision to release this man?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I do not believe that the Attorney-General of the day erred in his dealings with this matter. As I indicated in reply to Senator Sir John Carrick, all that the Attorney-General knew at the time he was making his decision was that the allegedly false passport had been in police possession for something over a month, or of the order of a month, and that, for whatever reason, no charge had been laid. No doubt if he had pursued the matter he would have appreciated that there was no barrier in law to a charge being made. Certainly, it did depend on the consent of the Department of Immigration, but there was no reason on the face of it why such consent should not have been given if indeed the evidence was such as to justify a charge being laid.

ANSWER.PARA: The facts as they were available to the Attorney-General of the day were such as to justify him, I believe, and Mr Menzies believes-he dealt with this matter very fully and reported to the Government-reaching the view that it was unconscionable in our system of justice for someone against whom a charge, for whatever reason, had not been laid to be kept in gaol on an open-ended basis, presumably while further investigations could take place. That might be the way in which some countries or indeed some honourable senators opposite might choose to run a judicial system, a criminal investigation system or a penal system, but it has not hitherto been the Australian way. I do not in any way divert from my support for the former Attorney-General for reaching the decision on the grounds that he apparently employed.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister for Social Security, refers to the present experiment by the National Party of Australia member for Hume, Mr Lusher, who intends to find out in one week whether the unemployment benefit is too high. In view of the realities of unemployment, does the Minister agree that such an experiment indicates a very simplistic mentality ? Is the Minister concerned that the experiment will be only an insult to genuine unemployed people who are desperate for more, not less, understanding and positive support from politicians?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I have noted the reports of Mr Lusher's publicity stunt which is being conducted in conjunction with a well known television program in this country. I do not know that we can-
—Why give him more?

—There is a statement condemning sin. As Senator Elstob said, there is no question that if this is intended to be a serious exercise it demonstrates a simplistic mentality. I think it demonstrates an extraordinary lack of sensitivity in this area on the part of Mr Lusher in particular and also the television program concerned. It was reported that Mr Lusher would forgo life's luxuries next week and go on the unemployment benefit in order to prove his personal theory-one which he has often espoused in the Parliament and outside-that people on the unemployment benefit receive so much money that there is insufficient incentive for them to try to find work. He is also known for his attacks on supporting parents and other pensioners and beneficiaries.

ANSWER.PARA: I believe this distasteful little stunt is an indication of Mr Lusher's immaturity and arrogance. His assumption that he can put himself in the position of someone who is unemployed, who is demoralised, and come out a week later with a certificate for good housekeeping is an appalling reflection on the way he thinks. The fact that the average duration of unemployment benefit payments is now in excess of, I think, 40 weeks demonstrates just how stupid Mr Lusher's exercise is. Of course the honourable member concerned will be employed all this time as usual in Parliament House, occupying a nice, centrally heated office. He will not face the loneliness or humiliation those on unemployment benefits face. I presume his wife and four children will still be living in Cootamundra, having all their bills paid and the security that no unemployed persons can have. Their schooling expenses will still be paid. Mr Lusher will still have deducted from his salary contributions to the parliamentary superannuation fund, providing for his retirement in a way that no unemployed person can ever do. How a well fed, wealthy person of this type can expect to prove anything in a week, I do not know.

Members of parliament had the unedifying spectacle this morning of seeing Mr Lusher, pack on back and on his bike, apparently trying to look like someone who is unemployed, hiding behind the bushes outside Parliament House waiting for the television cameras to turn up and take pictures of him. A shopkeeper reported on the radio this morning that Mr Lusher went to a supermarket in the Monaro Mall, did his shopping, took it out and put it in the 60 Minutes van and then got on his bike and rode off. This is an appalling farce and a disgraceful, insensitive display by Mr Lusher and by 60 Minutes. I do not think I have ever read an issue of the Canberra Times quite like this morning's issue. Everyone, from Professor Henderson to a local doctor and local citizens, roundly condemned Mr Lusher for carrying out this cheap stunt. As Professor Henderson said:
It's a very partial experiment-quite inadequate if he really wants to know what sorts of costs long-term unemployed people face.

The most he will find out is how much he will have left over after food. He just won't have the expenses of long-term unemployed. I doubt he will be buying clothes or shoes, paying an electricity or gas bill or paying rates.
One of the best statements in this morning's paper was that by Dr Frank Slater, who said:
I suggest Mr Lusher takes sardine sandwiches instead of vegemite sandwiches for lunch. Fish is supposed to be a brain food and he certainly needs it.

All this morning contempt and ridicule have been heaped on Mr Lusher as a result of this extraordinary state of affairs. One person stated that Mr Lusher's experiment was about as valuable as putting a first grade footballer in a wheelchair for a week and expecting him to be an expert on the problems faced by the disabled. I think 60 Minutes and Mr Lusher should seriously consider calling off this distasteful farce and leave the unemployed to what little dignity they have in going about their lives, trying to become productive citizens of this country. We can do without this sort of distasteful nonsense and, if Mr Lusher will not reconsider his position, I hope that his colleagues will reconsider it and somehow manage to get him to stop this nonsense.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Attorney-General seen a copy of an obscene publication entitled 'Your Rights 1984', written by a Mr John Bennett? Can the Attorney explain why such a person was invited to the National Crimes Commission Conference in July 1983, given his repeated assertions that the destruction of 6 million Jews in nazi Germany was a hoax perpetrated by Jews in order to drum up emotional support for Israel? Does the Minister believe that the Government ought to elevate the public status of an individual who has become so obsessed with this issue that his opinions are now those of a virulent anti-Semite, who knowingly would offend millions of decent people whose friends and relatives were deliberately and cold-bloodedly murdered by the Nazis? Is the Attorney- General concerned that Mr Bennett has urged unauthorised endorsements of individuals, including that of the Attorney-General as I understand it, to be seen, falsely, to be giving support to the offensive, immoral and obscene lies that Mr Bennett espouses with regard to the holocaust? Will the Minister assure the Senate that no Commonwealth Government funds have been used to support the so-called civil liberties organisation to which Mr Bennett claims he belongs or to fund the publication of 'Your Rights 1984'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen a copy of the booklet by John Bennett entitled 'Your Rights 1984' and I have moreover seen my name appearing on the back cover by way of an alleged endorsement of it. I will say something about that in a moment. Mr Bennett was not an invited participant in the National Crimes Commission Conference held in the middle of last year. He did seek the right to attend and he was in the event, along with a number of other people, given a limited status as an accredited observer, in which capacity he spoke, I think on one occasion. There was no question of his being given, any more than anyone else, any financial assistance to attend the conference. He attended in his capacity as a long standing alleged civil libertarian and former convenor of the Victorian Council for Civil Liberties and now a one-man organisation known as the Australian Civil Liberties Union. Mr Bennett, although he has been in many ways for a long time a distinguished advocate of civil libertarian causes in this country-albeit perhaps a slightly eccentric one-in recent years has been a constant source of dismay to those genuinely concerned with the protection and recognition of civil liberties. What I believe started out as a genuine concern for free speech, a genuine concern for the application of historiographical principles to the documentation of the Second World War and, I think, an intellectually defensible exercise in weighing the claims of the so-called revisionist historians about the Second World War, has now become clearly, in the words of Senator Chipp, an obsession on his part. His views over the years have become increasingly unattractive, increasingly unpalatable and, moreover I believe, increasingly intellectually indefensible.

ANSWER.PARA: Moreover, it is the case that Mr Bennett, simultaneously with this passion for rewriting the history of the Second World War and the holocaust, has become a staunch and very visible public defender of the re-establishment of the white Australia policy, and I suggest that those things are not entirely unconnected. I do not contest in any way, nor would any senator at least on this side of the Parliament, the right of Mr Bennett to express or indeed publish his views on this matter, but I certainly would not wish to associate myself or the Government in any way with the expression of the positions that he has increasingly taken and which he has now taken with a great deal of vigour and incongruity in chapter 14 of the 1984 edition of the booklet 'Your Rights 1984'. The booklet itself is primarily an updated rerun of material which ranks as a straightforward and helpful summary of citizens rights in a whole diversity of areas of criminal and civil law. As such-

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr President. The answers which have been given by the Attorney in Question Time this afternoon have been extremely long. I simply ask you to ask him to address the specific question in order to enable other questions to be asked.
—I have been listening carefully. I think the Attorney-General is addressing his answer to the question. There is no point of order. I call the Attorney-General.

—Some years ago I did write a review of an earlier edition of this book in which I said-it was published in the Age-that the booklet constituted a remarkable feat of compression and was well worth the $1.50 or whatever the cost was at the time that the review was first printed. That endorsement does in fact appear on the back of this latest booklet without any indication that the endorsement relates to an earlier edition rather than the present one. I find this attempt to use my name as an endorsement of the booklet to be false and indeed bordering on the fraudulent. The booklet contains, as I said, a chapter expounding Mr Bennett's views about the Second World War, which are palpably offensive and, I believe, quite indefensible. I totally disassociate myself from them. I condemn the deceptive use of my review, and indeed many other endorsements that are printed on the back of this, in an attempt clearly to promote sales of a work which, in its present form, contains views and opinions and alleged statements of fact which are not only inaccurate but also abhorrent and, I believe, indefensible.

—I ask the Minister for Veterans' Affairs: Has his Department taken any action, other than by newspaper advertisements, to advise disability pensioners who do not already receive a service pension that they may now be eligible to receive a service pension following changes in recent years in the treatment of their disability payments under the income test? Is it likely that significant numbers of veterans are unaware of their full entitlements? Will the Minister ensure that full information is made available to clients of his Department?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The previous Government, I think in 1980, established a task force to look at the problems of conveying to Australian citizens their rights under existing laws, relating not only to the Department of Veterans' Affairs but also to the Department of Social Security and other such government departments. Arising out of that task force it was found that tens of thousands of citizens were not aware of their rights as far as Commonwealth entitlements and facilities were concerned. However, it was not until last year that the Department of Veterans' Affairs decided to commission W. D. Scott and Co. Pty Ltd to evaluate the Government's public information program. The report on that evaluation, which is now available, to some extent answers the question that Senator Coates has asked of me because it makes it clear that thousands of veterans are not aware of their rights to benefits administered by my Department , and I am sure to benefits administered by many other government instrumentalities.

ANSWER.PARA: The survey that Scott carried out showed that of 2,000 veterans and war widows, only 57 per cent belonged to ex-service organisations, and 74 per cent would prefer to use departmental information channels but only 31 per cent did so. So it would appear that the Department, by placing emphasis upon conveying information through the ex-service community, has not in fact been reaching the very people it ought to reach, the people who should have had made available to them information about their particular rights in respect of disability pensions and the service pension. I think there is evidence that many veterans who are in receipt of disability pensions are not aware of the fact that having reached the age of 60, under certain criteria they are eligible for a service pension. Despite the efforts of the Department a lot more needs to be done. The report by W. D. Scott has made a number of serious recommendations which the Department is currently examining with a view to improving communication and therefore making available to people who, if made aware of their rights, would qualify for the many benefits available through the Department of Veterans' Affairs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. I ask the Minister: Can that report be made public or circulated to honourable senators?

—I do not see any particular difficulty in the report being made public. In fact I would be quite happy to table it. It is a rather large document. Sufficient copies are available for honourable senators. There is a precis of it here which I am quite happy to table. Having seen that, if honourable senators want copies of the report they will be made available.
—The document has been tabled.

—My question is addressed to the Attorney-General. I point out that the Government has now had three weeks to consider whether it will table the Menzies report into the Sala case. Will the Attorney now table the report? If not, why not?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has decided it will not table the Menzies report on the Sala affair of 1974, and there are four reasons which I would advance in support of an explanation of that decision. In the first place, the report is essentially that of a non-judicial investigation conducted to inform the Executive but not the general public, and its standing in that respect is not essentially different from the report of a law enforcement officer, which is traditionally not tabled. It will be recalled that police reports in the Age tapes matter were not tabled, and indeed will not be tabled or published by the Government.

ANSWER.PARA: The second point I make is that, in the view of the Government, the queries raised in relation to the Sala matter have been adequately answered by my letter to Mr Steele Hall of 5 March, by my letter to Mr Boyle of 16 March, and by the answers numerous and lengthy that I have given in Parliament in response to specific questions. In the Government's view, it would be over-dignifying the present attacks and innuendos to table the full report.

The third point I make is that not only is the report written for the information of Ministers rather than for general publication, but also it contains references-and this is a particularly important matter-to individuals, and especially allegations or suggestions reported by Mr Menzies to have been made by some individuals about other individuals that might reasonably be considered by the persons concerned as intrusions on their privacy or as otherwise offensive. I mention particularly in this respect that some of the individuals names in the report emerge at the end of the day and in the conclusions in the report as having only a remote connection with the central issues of the case; but it was necessary to explore their roles, their names having been mentioned in the course of the labyrinthine events surrounding this affair.

My fourth and final point is that, if tabled and if, as usual, a resolution to authorise publication were to be passed, subsequent publication of the document would be absolutely privileged in relation to defamation, and this would be inappropriate having regard to the real status of the document.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to standing order 363, I ask that the Minister table the document from which he is quoting.
—By all means.
—The Minister will table that document.

—I address my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. Since 1978 patients in approved non-government nursing homes have been required to contribute towards their care and treatment. Under regulation 29 such amount has been maintained at a level equivalent to 87.5 per cent of the sum of standard age pension and supplementary assistance payable under the Social Services Act 1947. Does this regulation also apply to long term geriatric patients in the Launceston General Hospital? Is there any special relief for elderly people maintaining a home while in short term hospital or nursing home care?

—Speaking from memory, I believe that Senator Hearn is right in her assertion that the fee in approved nursing homes is 87.5 per cent. I understand that that does not apply to those people who are long term patients in hospitals such as the Launceston General Hospital and who are there because of an inadequate number of other nursing home beds. I shall check the position with my colleague the Minister for Health and obtain a detailed answer for Senator Hearn. The only relief available to people in these circumstances in hospital is that the supplementary allowance, which is the rent allowance paid to eligible people on pensions, would still be paid. For instance, if they owned their own homes, there would be no relief. It is a matter in which we will take an interest, and matters of that sort certainly were taken into account when the Government planned the proposed assets test whereby we ensure that people would not be affected for at least 12 months after they went into such a nursing home. However, I shall find out from Dr Blewett the details required by Senator Hearn and give her a detailed answer as soon as possible.

—My question is directed to the Attorney-General. I refer him to the Prime Minister's response to a suggestion on the Sunday television program last Sunday that the question of the alleged conduct of the judge referred to in the Age tapes should be reviewed by a panel of his peers headed by the Chief Justice of the High Court of Australia. I ask the Attorney-General: Is he aware that the Prime Minister's response to this suggestion was that it was a novel suggestion which had some attractiveness? Has the Attorney-General given any consideration to the proposal? If so, what is his attitude to the proposal? Has he discussed it with his Cabinet colleagues? If so, has the Government made any decision in relation to it?

—The Government did give some consideration to this matter yesterday and resolved that although the proposal did have some elements that were attractive, as the Prime Minister said, basically it was not a proposal that was likely to be ultimately productive in satisfying everyone's concern about this particular matter. If there was any evidence that the Opposition is willing to accept the judgment of a group of the judge's judicial peers rather than pursuing the nonsense of a committee of inquiry, there might, of course, be something to be said for that. There does not seem to be, as I read it, much evidence that the Opposition is so minded. Equally, it would not appear that the proposal would have a great many attractions so far as the High Court is concerned, although its views have not been specifically sought by me. It might be thought to be a proposal which, while indeed having the attractions of a peer group review that were acknowledged by the Prime Minister, might nevertheless provide some difficulties, particularly of a technical kind, for the High Court. It is a proposal that was given due consideration but not thought in the event to be such as to warrant further pursuit.

—Has the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs read reports in the Press about allegations that she has refused to provide money for the Monash University Teaching Centre at the new Queen Victoria Hospital at Clayton in Victoria? Will the Minister inform the Senate whether those allegations have any foundation?

—I have read such reports in the Melbourne newspapers and I am amazed that those allegations continue to be made. I think they are being made by the Opposition in Victoria, which seems to be as devoid of ideas about how to promote its cause as the Opposition in this place. The fact of the matter is that Monash University has submitted a concept proposal to the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission for the construction of clinical teaching facilities in the new Queen Victoria Medical Centre. It has been advised that the proposal has been approved in concept at a figure of $6m. That figure is based on June 1982 cost values. This approval indicates the Commission's agreement that the proposal warrants consideration along with other proposals as funds become available. The matter has been the subject of extended discussions between the Commonwealth and Victorian governments. I am aware of the high priority accorded to the project in the State. I have asked the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission to ensure that the proposal is considered in accordance with the normal planning processes for the 1985-87 triennium.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. How many employees has the Health Insurance Commission recruited from the private health funds since August 1983? What is the total number of additional Health Insurance Commission employees since August 1983? How many of the non-private health fund employees were recruited on a temporary contract basis and how many on a permanent basis?

—I do not have the exact figures that Senator Martin asks for but I will certainly obtain them for her as soon as possible. When Medicare was introduced the Minister for Health announced, and I think I also said in answer to a question in this place, that we would be taking particular care to ensure that people employed by the private health insurance groups would receive preference for jobs. The Minister for Health has made certain efforts to ensure that this has happened. For instance, the Health Insurance Commission gives preference to former employees of health insurance funds. The Minister for Health has had consultations with various State Ministers for Health to see whether preference can be given to these employees by the State health departments. Discussions were held with the voluntary health insurance funds to ensure that we as a government knew just how many employees they were likely to put off. The restrictions on health insurance funds were lifted, as Senator Martin will know, to enable them to diversify their activities and in this way protect the jobs of those working in health insurance organisations. I know that the Minister for Health has the figures that Senator Martin requires. I will get them to her as soon as possible. I am sure I will be able to do so before the end of the week.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. The Minister will be aware of the damage caused in the Northern Territory, particularly at Borroloola, by Cyclone Kathy. Will the Minister indicate what action the Federal Government intends to take to assist those people at Borroloola who have been adversely affected by the cyclone?

—The damage to which Senator Robertson referred occurred last Friday morning, 23 March. I am advised that the emergency phase in relation to that cyclone is now over. I should say that a request came from the Northern Territory emergency services at the time of the cyclone for Royal Australian Air Force assistance. A Caribou aircraft and emergency supplies were sent to the area on Friday afternoon, some four hours, I believe, after the cyclone struck. On Friday afternoon the Prime Minister also sent a telex to the Northern Territory Government saying that the Federal Government stood ready to assist under the national disaster relief arrangements. As yet, there has been no reply from the Northern Territory Government to that offer from the Prime Minister last Friday. I am further advised that by Saturday, the day after the cyclone, all power and water supplies had been restored and the roads were open. So it appears that the worst effects of the cyclone were dealt with very quickly. Whether there will be any request from the Northern Territory under the national disaster relief arrangements remains to be seen.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I preface my question to the Attorney-General by referring him to the policy speech delivered by the Prime Minister on 16 February 1983 in the Sydney Opera House. The Prime Minister said, under the heading 'Law and Justice' :

QUESTION.PARA: Among the measures we will vigorously pursue are a national Bill of Rights.

I ask the Attorney-General: Is the Government vigorously pursuing this matter or have the realists in the Caucus again overruled the Attorney-General's proposal? If the decision has been taken not to proceed, is it intended to resurrect the proposal after the next election?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is vigorously pursuing the Bill of Rights initiative. It is just that it will take us a little longer to vigorously pursue it than was originally anticipated. The short explanation for the Government's decision to defer the introduction of this measure, whilst still approving it in principle, is this: The measure makes sense only in the context of a package of legislation including reforms to the restructuring of the Human Rights Commission because the Commission will have a very substantial role in relation to the implementation and, in a sense, the enforcement of the Bill of Rights as well as, of course, having its responsibilities under the Racial Discrimination Act and the new Sex Discrimination Act. It was believed originally that it would be possible to introduce this whole package of measures this session. The Bill of Rights part of the package is very close to fruition, although I was hoping for more substantial consultations with the States and other relevant interest groups before actual introduction. That part of the package dealing with the restructuring of the Human Rights Commission, however, was, because of the complexity of some of the issues that revealed themselves, lagging somewhat behind.

ANSWER.PARA: It became apparent that the whole package, including the machinery part of it, would not be ready for introduction until well into the Budget session. —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Has the Australian Government taken any action to condemn the use of chemical weapons in the Iraq-Iran war? Secondly, what steps does the Government intend to take to ensure that such chemical weapons are outlawed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Hayden, has made a number of public statements today since the report to the United Nations Secretary-General was released in New York yesterday, 26 March; that is, the report of a team of experts, including Australian defence scientist, Dr Peter Dunn, who was sent to Iran to investigate reports that chemical weapons had been used in the Iran-Iraq war. That report concluded, as honourable senators will be aware, that two chemical agents, sulphur mustard and tabun, have been used in the areas visited by the experts. Sulphur mustard is a blistering agent which was used widely in World War I and was responsible for the majority of gas casualties in that war. Tabun is a chemical weapon developed by nazi Germany during the Second World War. It is an extremely lethal nerve agent which kills with a quite horrific and agonising effect.

ANSWER.PARA: It is the firm view of the Government, as would no doubt be expected, that there can be no justification whatever for the use of these barbaric weapons, which constitutes a clear breach of international law. Both Iraq and Iran, as well as Australia, are parties to the 1925 Geneva Protocol which prohibits the use of chemical weapons. The Minister for Foreign Affairs also briefs me that he has instructed his Department to raise the whole question once more with the Iraqi Government in the light of the United Nations report, and Australia's missions to the United Nations and elsewhere will also be initiating urgent consultation on what measures the international community can take against further use of these weapons.

The Australia-Japan Foundation has operated since 1976. This report concerns the 1982-83 financial year. Members of the Foundation are appointed by the Minister for Foreign Affairs. The legislation provides for up to 15 members of the Foundation. Currently the principal members include representatives of business, the academic world, the Public Service and the community. The Foundation's major functions are to encourage closer relationships between Australia and Japan and to further the mutual understanding between our two countries. Also, it has been given the function of promoting study in each country of the language, culture and tradition of the other. The Foundation was also established to encourage visits of groups and citizens between the two countries.

Unfortunately, during 1982-83 the Foundation was hit, as were many other authorities, by the so-called razor gang. As a result of the cut-backs enforced by that body, two staff positions were lost which represented quite a significant reduction in the Foundation's staffing level. Further, in the 1982- 83 Budget there was a 10 per cent cut in funds available to the Foundation. According to this annual report, this considerably dislocated the Foundation's activities. The Australia-Japan Foundation is now seeking the restoration of funding, in real terms, to previous levels.

Relations between Australia and Japan are now at an important stage. We are major trading partners. Japan is a major and vital market for Australian iron ore, coal, wool and beef but at present there is concern in some organisations about Australia's market share of key commodities. I instance coal and beef. Recently the Government had discussions with the Japanese Government about reports that Australia is to lose part of its share of the beef market in Japan. Traditionally we have supplied some 65 per cent of that market and unofficial reports appearing in the Press indicated that larger quotas were to be given to the United States, to the disadvantage of Australian beef producers. I welcome the Government's actions in stepping in and making its views known on that matter.

Recently the Japanese Prime Minister made some interesting comments about the need for further co-operation among the Pacific Basin countries. These views are particularly interesting, given that the two largest industrial nations in the world now border either side of the Pacific Ocean-the United States, the largest industrial nation, and Japan, the second largest industrial nation. Certainly the emphasis in world trade and affairs must be shifting to the Pacific region as a result of the emergence of Japan as a major industrial power. A study of Pacific Basin trade flows and investment flows between the major countries, as proposed by Mr Nakasone, would be very useful and something in which the Australian Government could play a role. I certainly took note of the comments made by Mr Hawke late last year in Thailand when he called for countries of the western Pacific region to work together, for example, to secure generally agreed objectives such as common positions in multilateral trade negotiations. Of course Japan would be a major party to those negotiations.

An opportunity for members of Parliament to study and learn about Japan is provided under the biennial exchange provided for in the agreement between the two countries. Together with other members of this chamber, I visited Japan last year as a member of the all party exchange. We inspected, at our request, Japanese high technology industry. The steel and motor vehicle industries were other industries that we had the opportunity of visiting. We were struck by developments in the Japanese computer industry but noted some concern among Japanese industrialists that, while a relatively high percentage of expenditure is devoted to research and development, a relatively small proportion of that amount actually goes to original research and development. A major debate is occurring in Japan about the level of original research and the relatively higher level of moneys being spent on development and application rather than on the development of new ideas.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: DEFENCE FORCE RETIREMENT AND DEATH BENEFITS AUTHORITY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

This report has arrived on our desks somewhat earlier than the report in respect of the year 1981-82 which arrived immediately after the mini-Budget, as I recall it, last May. The point raised by the Opposition about that report at that stage was whether there would be any specific exemptions in respect of taxation to be applied to lump sum superannuation payments payable to Defence Force personnel. Apparently in the course of the last ten or so months the Government has considered this matter but has not moved in any particular way to exempt Defence Force personnel from its proposed legislation. I hasten to add that in fact no legislation has been brought down notwithstanding that we were first given notice of the Government's proposal some ten months ago. During the period since then we have been wallowing in ignorance of the Government's final intentions in this area. Of course, the matter has been the subject of the same kinds of connotations as were applied to the Government's disastrous handling of the proposed assets test legislation. Clearly, the Government is headed for another disaster with this one.

It is significant to note that the Government failed to introduce the legislation ahead of the New South Wales election. That, of course, is an obvious example of its trying to hoodwink the voters in that State about the state of the Government's legislative program but, more particularly, to give some indication to them that, in light of its actions over the assets test legislation, it is also reconsidering the effect of lump sum superannuation tax. I think we have to acknowledge that the Government has shown some common sense in this regard by moving in such an obtuse way as to allow Defence Force personnel to commute the four-year pension to a five-year pension. That has yet to be confirmed, as I said, because we have not seen any legislation. But the net effect of that action, naturally enough, is to make sure that each Defence retiree receives less in the way of pension to keep himself alive after his retirement. So it is not as though any concession has been given to Defence Force personnel by the Government's action in lump sum superannuation; in fact, the reverse is true because over a period the Defence Force retiree will have lost the value of that taxation from his net benefits. I think it needs to be said that the Government appears to have lost its sense of direction on the whole question of retirement policy. That has been acknowledged by the Government through its past actions in relation to the assets test. It is pretty clear too that the people of Australia have acknowledged that in the course of election campaigns run since May 1983.

I think the Government is labouring under a basic misapprehension on the whole question of lump sum superannuation and indeed ought to come to its senses about the tax treatment of this matter. In fact the whole justification for the Government's imposition of the tax has been on the basis that there is somehow some inequity between the way in which lump sums are treated for tax purposes and the way in which annuities and pensions are treated; that is, that only 5 per cent of a lump sum is included for income tax purposes in the year that it is received whereas the tax on annuities and pensions is payable in full each year. The point has to be made that in fact once a lump sum is invested the investment return from that sum is taxable in the same way as is a pension and an annuity. Therefore, how can it be argued that there is inequity in the treatment of that? Indeed the original premise for the establishment of the lump sum taxation regime was simply that tax was to be collected from that lump sum in the first year to ensure that some part of it was brought to tax that year. Thereafter the investment return will suffer tax in the same way as annuities and pensions do at present. We, on this side, see very little difference in the overall tax treatment.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
