This statement was made by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr West) in the House of Representatives on 7 March 1984. I do not intend to traverse the same area as was covered by the shadow Minister for Immigration, Mr Michael Hodgman. I wish to raise a couple of other issues that I think arise out of the Minister's statement. Last year the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs made a statement to the Parliament on the Government's objectives and priorities in relation to Australia's immigration program. At the time he said that he wanted to change the emphasis-on some occasions he called it the bias-of the previous Government's immigration program. Certain targets were set for the Hawke Government in terms of numbers and priorities.

The statement by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, delivered recently in the House of Representatives, outlined a number of failures in terms of targeted immigration programs and the bases of such programs. The Minister stated that the Government's original immigration intake expectations for 1983- 84 were in the range of 82,000 to 90,000 people. In the statement made on 7 March 1984 that estimate has been revised downwards to a figure of 70,000. The Minister criticised the Fraser Government for the fact that in 1982-83 there were 83,000 arrivals in Australia. He criticised it on a number of grounds, including whether the Fraser Government had reached the targets it had set itself and announced specifically in the family reunion category. The Minister pointed out that the targets set by the Fraser Government in 1982-83 were not met in the family reunion category and instanced that as a criticism of the program. Nevertheless, in 1982-83 the Fraser Government's program was so successful that 13,000 more people came to Australia than the present Government will manage in 1983-84, despite the fact that the Government set itself a higher target than that achieved by the Fraser Government in 1982-83. It had set an upper target, a ceiling, of 90,000.

TALK.START.PARA: —You said 125,000.

—If Senator Robertson reads my speech, he will understand the point I am making. The area on which the Minister dwelt in his statement is category C, involving family reunions of brothers, sisters and non-dependent children. He pointed out that the family reunion numbers will not be more than 16,000 in that category and that applications and admissions have fallen far short of what was anticipated. I am puzzled by that. A large number of immigration representations go through my office. The area in which I meet with the greatest change in effect of the Government's policy in terms of success in this family reunion category involves adult brothers or sisters and their families, people who migrated to this country some time ago. That is the most difficult area. I have one case where a family, middle-aged people, had had indicated to them that they would be allowed to come. This was at a time when assets were a factor-a factor which has now been downgraded by the present Government. Members of the family had sold their homes, but when the official letter came from Australia House they were told that they had been rejected. They have, of course, lodged an appeal, but that is fairly typical of cases that occurred last year. By rearranging its priorities, the Government is discriminating against these people.

SPEECH.PARA: I suggest to the Minister that, since his targets are falling so far short of what the Government had hoped for, he might re-examine this area. The Minister, quite rightly, in his statement to Parliament last year said that nobody should be able to buy his or her way into Australia, and I agree with that. But we are talking of people who have families here, who are established, who have been here for some time, and who have independent means of support and money to invest in this country. Australia needs that investment. We have been hearing from the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in recent times how much this country needs investment because such investment means jobs for Australians, yet such people are being downgraded in their eligibility. The fact that they have money to invest and can be self-sufficient is no longer as important a category as it used to be, and the Government denies its own economic priorities.
I have almost exhausted my time in this debate and I shall refer to only one more matter. The Minister said in his recent statement:
. . . on balance the Government feels that the changes made to the points assessment systems last May--
which is the system about which I have been speaking-
have already significantly moderated previous bias in favour of highly skilled, English speaking, youthful and affluent migrants.

I do not know whether it was a bias but, whatever it was, I ask the Minister: What is wrong with highly skilled, English speaking, youthful and or affluent migrants? I do not say they are the only desirable migrants, but I would have thought that they were desirable traits in migrants. Something in our program that encouraged people with those characteristics would possibly be a good aspect. Perhaps the Government might rethink its views and stop referring to these things as a bias as though they were something negative.

—I join in debate on the statement on the migration program very briefly to say that I agree with the remarks of the two previous speakers. It seems to me quite ridiculous that people who would like to come to this country, people who would add to likely employment rather than be a cost to the country, find great difficulty in getting into Australia.
—This is the business category?

—It is the business category I believe the honourable senator spoke about a moment ago. I believe the Government should look at this category very closely. We should look at our traditional areas as well as these other areas that are now being gone into.

SPEECH.PARA: For the benefit of honourable senators, officials and others likely to be dealing with the Committee and the public generally, I turn now to the functions of the Committee. The Committee, as expeditiously as is practicable, considers each public work that is referred to it in accordance with the Public Works Committee Act and makes a report to both Houses of Parliament concerning the expedience of carrying out the work. It also reports on any other matters related to the work in respect of which it thinks it desirable that its views should be reported to both Houses. It may recommend any alterations to the proposals for the work that, in its opinion, are necessary or desirable to ensure that the most effective use is made of the moneys to be expended on the work.

It is the practice for the Chairman of the Committee to read out sub-section 17 (3) of the Public Works Committee Act at the commencement of each public hearing . This sets out the pertinent matters to be taken into consideration when the Committee reports on a public work. Honourable senators may be assured that the members of the twenty-seventh Committee will continue to uphold the tradition of all former committees in its important role as a watchdog, on behalf of Parliament, over proposed expenditure on public works. I commend the report to honourable senators.

DEBATE.TITLE: NATIONAL ADVISORY AND CO-ORDINATING COMMITTEE ON MULTICULTURAL EDUCATION

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-For the information of honourable senators, I present details of the membership of the National Advisory and Co-ordinating Committee on Multicultural Education. The establishment of this Committee was recommended by the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs following its evaluation of post-arrival programs and services in 1982. This Government endorsed the proposal in September last year and in November placed advertisements in the national Press calling for nominations. Communities and other interest groups were also asked to advise their members of the establishment of the Committee. I am confident that, on examining the membership list, honourable senators will agree that this group of people does just that.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee will fill an important role in providing advice on the needs of multicultural education for those in schools and tertiary institutions and for those outside the formal education system. More specifically, the Committee will advise me on matters relating to multicultural education; co-ordinate, monitor and review multicultural programs and activities; and determine an appropriate procedure for information exchange on multicultural education and put that procedure into practice.

This Government believes it is essential that our education system should adequately accommodate the changing ethnic composition of the Australian community. There is considerable ethnic diversity in our society. This provides excellent opportunities for cultural and educational enrichment. For too long this wealth of cultural resources has been ignored or under utilised. This Committee should help to change that situation. It will help to identify those resources and to advise on how best they can be tapped and drawn upon for the benefit of all Australians. I am sure that honourable senators will agree that the establishment of the Committee is long overdue and will enhance the Commonwealth's efforts in multicultural education, extensive as these already are.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

The Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan) indicated that the establishment of the National Advisory and Co-ordinating Committee on Multicultural Education arose out of the work of the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs which conducted an evaluation of post-arrival programs and services in 1982. This was an evaluation initiated by the former Government. I am delighted to see that the present Government is acting upon the recommendations from that evaluation. It was a Fraser Government initiative but it required follow-up action. We appreciate that the Hawke Government is doing this.

I do not know all the members appointed to the Committee. I therefore offer no comments upon whether they will be suitable for the job which the Minister has set for them. However, we wish them well in trying to achieve what the Minister has said are the objectives: to enhance the Commonwealth's efforts in multicultural education. Professor Jayasuriya is known to us from his work. I am delighted to see Ms Margaret Valadian's name on the list because we know of her work in Aboriginal education.

A couple of points need to be made in relation to the work done by AIMA when it carried out the evaluation of post-arrival programs and in relation to what the Government expects from this new Committee. First, I would have thought that the main thrust of the work done in the evaluation should have related to outcomes. It was my impression-I put this on record publicly-that one of the grave deficiencies of the evaluation by AIMA was that it concentrated largely on structure and process and was often very intrusive in the recommendations that it made in various departmental functions. To my mind, whilst it was extremely detailed and prescriptive, it was not what I would have thought was one of the best evaluations I have seen. I did not think all its recommendations were terribly good. I refer particularly to its quite prescriptive recommendations in relation to the structure and conduct of technical and further education in Australia. That evaluation recommended the ways in which certain moneys available to TAFE should be spent in certain programs. In fact, it hypothecated them and made the moneys unavailable for any other purpose. I am sorry that that course was followed. There was considerable public disquiet from within the technical and further education sector when that course was followed.

I return to the question of outcomes. I observe to the Minister that there is nothing in her statement which really talks about the outcomes she wants to achieve either for multicultural education as a result of this Committee being established or for mainstream education and its appreciation of multicultural needs. This Committee is a new structure and a new group. It will meet, its members will talk with each other and will no doubt interview people. However, unless it produces outcomes which will do something for education in Australia then it will not have proven itself or justified its existence. This Committee may be an eminent one, but I believe that the challenge for it is that, in a year or so, it will look back on what it has done, carry out an evaluation and look for outcomes which it has produced for education in Australia. For my part, that is how I will judge it. I will not judge it by the way it has met, the frequency of its meetings or by the kind of recommendations it puts out. In the end I will judge it upon its capacity to alter education in Australia to produce better results for multicultural and mainstream education in ways which are probably desirable having regard to the kind of society which the Minister has identified and the kind of community which she identified in her statement.

Having said all that, we wish the Committee well. We will watch with some interest to see whether it can influence or alter what is done in Australia or whether it is just one more group meeting and talking to itself and no doubt imagining it is doing marvellous things if nothing changes on the ground.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Townley Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are discussing the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1983 to which the Opposition has foreshadowed an amendment. I intervene briefly in the debate to outline a couple of my policies on taxation. Of course, taxation is one of the main interests of the public. I think nearly every person who gets a pay slip each week scans it to see what has happened with the rates of taxation. Many have noticed recently that the amount taken for taxation has increased due to the Medicare levy. Of course, most people would prefer to see their rates of taxation decreasing. I cannot see that happening for a long time because at the moment this Government is very much a taxing government. Somehow this year it has got away with imposing a huge deficit on this country. It has blamed the previous Government for it but I do not believe that blame is properly placed upon the previous Treasurer of the previous Government.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government used the foreshadowed deficit, before any adjustment by the previous Government, to get into the pattern of things that those of us who have been here during the term of Labor Party governments recognise; that is, they just love to spend money. They seem always to take the line that leads Australia to become more deeply in debt.

A few minutes ago I was looking at figures that show that in this country we are now spending almost as much on interest bills as we are on education- certainly within a few percent. If the trends that are obvious from the graphs I drew from those figures continue, next year we will spend more on interest than we do on education. At the moment our interest bill, as a part of the total Budget outlays, is over 7 per cent. It has been going up quite dramatically over the last two years. I believe that during the time of the Liberal Government there was an attempt, if one looks at the graph, to contain the percentage of Budget outlays spent on interest payments. That is one of the reasons why the Liberal Party was trying so hard to keep the Budget deficits under control. To say that it would have allowed a deficit of the magnitude that is being seen by this country in today's climate is absolute rubbish.

For the record, we are now in debt per head by about 20 per cent more than Argentina, Brazil, Mexico, Chile or Poland. They are the countries that the International Monetary Fund is quite worried about. In fact, during the weekend there were articles in the local Press showing the concern of that Fund about what is going on in those countries. If we are not very careful in this country we could be placed under the same kind of restrictions that are being enforced on those countries if they are to get the money they need to keep the country rolling. If, perchance, Japan did not continue to buy our iron and coal, if the left wing of the Labor Party got away with restricting sales of uranium and if we had a bad year for wheat, this country would be in quite a mess. We could easily be placed in the same kind of situation as that of the countries I mentioned a moment ago.

I have been taking a look ahead at taxes. I think that under Labor they will do nothing but increase. I believe that governments have the right, if taxes are to increase, to decide how they will be increased. If they want to increase pay as you earn tax it is their decision. If they want to increase excise duties, payroll tax or sales tax, as has been done, that is entirely their decision. But I do not believe that governments have any right to take money from people retrospectively. That is the real reason I have entered this debate. I do not believe that the Government has any right, for example-I am not suggesting for a moment it is doing it in this case-to apply retrospectivity to pay as you earn tax. The Government for one reason or another toward the end of a financial year could bring in legislation that imposed taxation right back to the beginning of the financial year or even further. We have seen situations-Liberal-Country party governments have been as much at fault as Labor Party governments-in which taxes brought in in the Budget towards the end of August have been backdated to the beginning of July. That is entirely wrong. I believe that any taxation imposed should be imposed only from the date of its announcement. This has been said by several other people in this place today. To do otherwise, I believe, is unfair and dishonest. It almost becomes a matter of stealing from a person money that he may have already spent.

I have always opposed retrospective taxation for whatever reason. I opposed it when the Liberal-Country Party Government was in power and I always will oppose it. In the times I have spoken previously on this matter I have said that I believe that retrospectivity in taxation should be unconstitutional. In fact, I have had a referendum Bill in my desk for several years. I believe that if such a referendum were presented to the public of this country people would wholeheartedly support it. I do not believe that the people of this country are automatically against referenda. Referenda are usually brought in because a government wants to get something. It does not want to give the public something ; it wants to make life easier for itself. That seems to be the way with many referenda that have been in and out of this place over the time I have been here . Very few of them really do much for the public. They seem to do things for government and that is why the voter tends to kick them out. Voters should never be under- estimated. I have always had a high admiration for the intelligence of the public. People can understand the difference between making something illegal retrospectively and otherwise. I will be voting to oppose any retrospective clauses in this Bill. In other words, I will be supporting the moves by the Opposition to get rid of the retrospectivity and, if those clauses cannot be removed, I will vote against the whole Bill. As I said, the Government has the right to decide how it will tax the people of this country. People had better believe that they will be taxed very heavily over the next few years. Governments have a right to impose taxation from a certain time but in my opinion they have absolutely no right to impose tax retrospectively.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the second reading of the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1983. It is an important Bill insofar as it deals with taxation and, as Senator Townley said, this is now a matter of major public concern because we face ever-increasing taxation. That should not be a surprise to anyone who knows anything about Australian politics because the Australian Labor Party is always indissolubly linked with high taxation policies. We are suffering high taxation at the present time-an increasing level of high taxation, as Senator Townley said-because of the lack of business understanding and the lack of feeling for how to manage the economy that is manifested so much in this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: It is worth reminding the Australian public that one of the big problems we suffer is the problem of inflation. We thank for inflation the Whitlam Government of 1972 to 1975 which blew apart the Australian economy. We tried to control it and, in fact, we went a long way towards controlling it in the years we were in government. But now we are faced with a reckless and irresponsible deficit. This year's deficit is absolutely inexcusable. It should have been wound back because of the increase in the state of the economy which has come from the breaking of the drought, the consequences of the improvement in overseas trade and the effects of the pay pause which was introduced by the Federal Liberal Government which preceded this Government. We have a deficit that is comparable in respect of gross national product to the horrendous United States deficit.

How many people in Australia realise that the deficit position that the Labor Party has put us into is every bit as bad as the deficit that the United States Government suffers at present? It is not a paper entry; it is a fact of life. Senator Townley rightly drew the attention of members of this chamber to the fact that we will pay more and more for the interest on that debt because of the borrowings that the Government has to enter into. Australians will have to pay more by way of interest rates on our homes, cars and everything that we buy because of the competition in the market-place from Government bond issues.

TALK.START.PARA: —It brings more unemployment, too.

—Yes, there will be increasing unemployment. Investors and business people say: 'Why should we invest when there is no return and if we are to be ripped off by a rapacious Labor Government?' During the New South Wales election campaign in the streets of Sydney the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) begged: 'Please invest more'. Nothing happened. It is a simple business equation.

SPEECH.PARA: If we look at the increase in taxation which will arise through the introduction of Medicare we will see what an immoral proposition it is. The Government will never make Medicare work. The problems will run on for ages. How can the Government tax people for a system at the rate of one per cent, 2 per cent next year or 3 or 4 per cent and then not deliver the goods? The Government should have fixed up the problems before it introduced Medicare.

I return to the point on which I started: There is a need for taxation reform in this country; there is a need for a simple system of levying tax, a system which everyone can understand. Above all, there is a need for an incentive so that people will produce and be creative in a commercial sense. That is the only way we will ever get the unemployment rate down. It is the only way we will grow and develop as a country.

The Labor Party has no intention of bringing in an incentives system. It does not want people to earn money because it is very much part of the socialist objective that people become dependent on the state. A fundamental part of that is to deprive them of their own capital so that they do not have any independence and ultimately lose their freedom.

Two parts of the Bill have attracted my attention. The first concerns tax avoidance practices in relation to superannuation funds. The second concerns the special concessions in relation to Australian trading ships. Dealing with the tax avoidance practices in relation to superannuation funds, I indicate that I have no truck at all with dishonest perpetrators of schemes, that is, those who are involved in fraud. I will support any government that wants to stamp out fraud in that way. Where I depart from supporting this Government is in respect of the retrospectivity aspect of this part of the Bill. It is not my fault; it is the fault of incompetent bureaucrats that legislation has stayed in place for years and has not been corrected. Now that legislation has been brought forward I am prepared to support it, but I am not prepared to go back and deprive people who, in the main, entered into commercial agreements in good faith.

Before the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh) flies to his feet and asks me where I was in previous times, I will reaffirm for his knowledge that I was the first person in my State, and probably in the whole of the country, to oppose retrospective taxation moves. I voted against them when they were introduced by the previous Government. I have no problems at all with the prospective clauses of this Bill, but I have a total incompatibility with the retrospective elements and I will vote against the clause in accordance with the Opposition's amendment. If the Government does not have the sense to accept that , I will have to vote against the whole Bill despite the fact that there are some very good parts in it that need supporting.

The second part of the Bill to which I want to refer concerns the special concessions for Australian trading ships. I have no quarrel with this part of the Bill. I think that the intention of this part of the Bill is excellent. In the longer term it aims to re-establish the Australian merchant marine, which is something that is long overdue in the national interest. An effective merchant marine is a national asset. I believe that rail and sea transport in Australia has been grossly underused and mismanaged through this century. There are great economic benefits to this country in our having a good and efficient merchant marine and a good rail system. The rail services in the States have been mismanaged by government monopoly controls. Regrettably, the merchant marine has suffered at the hands of the Australian union movement. But there is a real place for that service where bulk cargo is to be moved and where speed is not a parameter. There is also a very important national benefit with respect to defence in possessing efficient transport services in both those mediums. With respect to the sea, the Waterside Workers Federation of Australia ashore and the seagoing unions have killed the goose that laid the golden egg.
The part of the Bill that interests me is the part to which the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) referred in his second reading speech. He said:
In addition, the level at which the ship is manned must not exceed the level determined for that ship by the Secretary to the Department of Transport.

In other words, to qualify for the 20 per cent depreciation allowance on or after 29 July 1977, the ship must be manned in accordance with a figure put forward by the Secretary to the Department of Transport. I cannot resist making the comment that if I had $20m and wished to build a factory or buy plant or anything like that I would be entitled to claim a 20 per cent depreciation allowance without any reference at all to how many people I employed. Yet if I build a ship for the same amount, $20m, I have to comply with a requirement of the Department of Transport as to how many seamen or crew members I can put on board that ship. Be that as it may-it is a bit of an irrelevance-the importance of this clause is that there is no definition as to how the number of people manning a ship is arrived at. There is no explanation of the formula that might be used to arrive at the manning number. I would presume that if a shipowner did not meet the level determined for that ship by the Secretary to the Department of Transport he would receive none of his depreciation allowance. If that is so, I think it is unfair. Clearly, any improvement in productivity should be rewarded by the Government. As a legislator, I think that it is bad legislation not to have this definition. Its omission will make trouble in the future. It also places a very great responsibility on the Department of Transport. Regrettably, we cannot have the Secretary to the Department of Transport present at the Committee stage. If he were present I would like to ask him whether he welcomed this move and what his qualifications were to comment on how many crew members should be employed on a ship.

Improving productivity and thereby getting costs down for the Australian merchant marine are worthwhile objectives but in this way it is a very cowardly path for the Government to follow. We have a circuitous route of the Government, in secret, telling the Secretary to the Department of Transport how many crew members there should be on a particular ship. Then we have the Secretary to the Department of Transport telling the shipowners, presumably in public, that they can have only so many crew members and then the shipowners having to tell the unions: 'Sorry, you can only have 20 people instead of the 40 people that you want on the ship'. Quite simply, that does not work. The Bill says that one may:

. . . request the Secretary to vary the manning notice and, where the Secretary receives such a request, has had regard to any relevant industrial relations considerations and is satisfied that the manning notice in force in relation to the ship is no longer appropriate by reason of . . .

What does that mean? Does it mean that if the shipowner has said to the unions that he needs to lower the manning strength, the unions will comply with his request? If they do not, does the ship- owner then go back to the Department of Transport and say: 'I am sorry, I tried and I can't get the manning figures down '? How does this square with the statements of the Minister for Transport, Mr Morris, in another place when he said that shipowners must be able to finance and man them competently?
That was in relation to the manning of ships. Later in the speech, he said he had no support at all for seagoing unions which did not come to grips with modernisation of shipboard practice.

Those of us who take some interest in union affairs will remember the River Boyne incident in Gladstone Harbour, Queensland, at the end of 1982. It was a bulk ship which was tied up for a very long period at a cost of millions of dollars. It was a coal burning ship that had just come on the run. That was a disastrous strike. Does anyone believe that that strike would have been averted by legislation such as this? I do not believe we can come to that conclusion. I support the intention of this part of the Bill but, as I have indicated, my concern is with how it will be implemented. One of the issues here is that of demarcation. We have far too many unions in the Australian maritime field. We have the Federated Marine Stewards and Pantrymens Association of Australasia, the Marine Cooks, Bakers and Butchers Association of Australasia, the Australian Institute of Marine and Power Engineers, the Merchant Service Guild of Australia , the Seamens Union of Australia, the Professional Radio and Electronics Institute of Australasia and the Professional Divers Association of Australasia. Those seven unions, and I think another three or four minor or State unions, are involved in the maritime trade.

I return to the dispute involving the River Boyne. The owners of that ship reduced the manning strength dramatically. Most of the unions, including the Seamens Union and the Institute of Marine and Power Engineers, co-operated in that regard. All gave ground except the Merchant Service Guild of Australia. It ended up with one shipwright left in the crew. That was the sticking point. One remembers the long argument about who would drop a rope over a bollard to moor the ship. It was an issue of the utmost triviality. The fundamental point is that, because of the demarcation disputes among the unions, the matter was insoluble.

I do not know how it was resolved. There was no way of arbitrating at the time to get over this point of demarcation. Surely if Mr Morris is serious in his claim that he wants to see modern manning practices in the Australian merchant marine area, the very first thing for the Government to do is amalgamate these seaborne unions which are now relics from the past.

Incidentally, the ship owners in this case did achieve quite an increase in productivity. A manning strength of 31 was used on the River Boyne and that gave a 63 per cent increase in productivity with regard to tonnes per crew member per year. That is a very significant increase. The suggestion is that the departmental figure for manning strengths for that ship is 29, which would give a theoretical improvement in productivity of 74 per cent. If that figure is true , if the Department of Transport does have in mind a manning strength lower than that which was achieved by the owners, Bulkships Ltd, would the Minister for Resources and Energy be able in the Committee stage to inform us as to how the owners are to get another two members out of the crew? It may be with a reduction of that order that the owners could reduce the crew by several more because the number of stewards and cooks might be able to be reduced.

Beyond this matter of demarcation, we come to a larger issue facing Australia- that of compulsory unionism and the closed shop of the waterfront. That leads to all the matters such as overtime and penalty rates and the fact that Australian crews do nothing other than carry out pure watchkeeping duties. They cannot be used for maintenance work while they are at sea or in harbour the way they were in former times and the way crews from other countries are used at present. As Senator Hamer said, that leads to our having two crews for every ship on the Australian coast. That is an enormous overhead, an overhead which other maritime powers do not have to put up with. We need some competition in the market place for the supply of labour. We can have that as soon as we grow up and get away from the closed shop approach to the supply of labour which pervades the whole of the Australian labour market. It is worth commenting on the changes that have taken place in the United States. The United States was never raddled with unionism the way Australia is. The union component in the United States work force never got beyond 33 per cent. At present it is just below 15 per cent and falling. If we compare the productivity of workers in the United States with the productivity of workers in Australia, we find that there is a glaring discrepancy.

I support the intention of this section of the legislation dealing with the manning of Australian ships but I do believe that the Bill is unworkable in the way it is worded and time will prove that the Government will have to come back, have the courage of its convictions, and tackle the fundamental cause of the lack of commercial competitiveness of Australian maritime traders. It will simply have to get rid of the multitude of unions and break the closed shop hold that the unions have on the supply of labour for the Australian maritime industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to address my remarks directly to at least one clause of the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill (No. 5). I do not wish to debate all the issues raised either today or the last time this matter came before the Senate. I shall simply raise two matters, one of which was raised by Senator Missen. He wondered why the Government did not take the opportunity that this Bill afforded it to address itself to the very real question that I raised on 25 May 1983, which dealt with bushfire relief donations and tax deductions. I asked the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Walsh:

SPEECH.PARA: Is the Minister representing both the Treasurer and the Minister for Finance aware of the different attitude being taken by the Australian Taxation Office in relation to donations of cash as distinct from donations in kind for the victims of the Victorian and South Australian bushfires? To give an example-
this example was given in a letter written to me-

there was an appeal for fodder and dairy cattle for the farming victims and a number of dairy farmers, including Tasmanians, made contributions of dairy cattle. Is it a fact that the Australian Taxation Office has decided to interpret certain provisions in the Income Tax Assessment Act so as to require farmers who make donations of farm produce and livestock to charitable appeals to pay tax on the value of such gifts? If so, is that not distinct from the attitude of the Commonwealth in respect of these appeals?
The Minister, in his reply, said:

In reply to the first part of Senator Harradine's question, I am not aware of what distinctions, if any, the Taxation Office is drawing between donations of cash and donations in kind. I will seek that information from the Minister. I can, however, see that an argument could be mounted for making a distinction between the two types of donations. Expenses incurred by a farmer in producing the two commodities that Senator Harradine has cited-fodder and animals-have been tax deductible. If, in addition to that, the item that was donated was allowed as a tax deduction at full market price there would be an element of double counting. Whether that is the basis for the Taxation Office's distinction , if in fact it draws such a distinction, I do not know. But I just raise the point that that could well be the case. I will seek a definitive answer from the Minister.

No response from the Minister has been forthcoming to me. Of course, that reference by Senator Walsh is an inadequate basis for any distinction to be made between donations in cash and donations in kind. I mention to the Senate that I was not the first person to raise this question, although at the time I thought I was. The honourable member for Murray, Mr Bruce Lloyd, actually raised the matter in the House of Representatives on 21 April. I raised it on 25 May, Senator Missen raised it with the Minister on 28 July, and on 24 August Senator Chipp proposed a private members Bill to remove this serious anomaly. In his response to the second reading stage, I would like to hear what the Minister has to say about this anomaly.

The second matter I wish to raise today relates to clause 5 of the Bill. In his second reading speech, in relation to the amendment to clause 5, the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) said:

This amendment is directed against a particularly distasteful tax avoidance practice containing clear elements of fraud against both the revenue and unsuspecting employees. It will, in accordance with the Government's announced policy in relation to blatant tax avoidance practices, apply with retrospective effect from 1 July 1977.
He went on to talk about the schemes and then said:

This is done in circumstances where the accumulated assets of the funds are paid out, not to the employees, but to the proprietors of the business concerned . The procedure is possible because employees are either not informed of their rights under the superannuation scheme or have their employment terminated in circumstances where they become disentitled to benefits from the fund.

What does the Government do? It does nothing about the affected employees. All it proposes is to introduce retrospective tax legislation to benefit the Treasury. I foreshadowed on 6 March 1984 that I would move an amendment-it has been circulated-to the second reading motion which will go to this very question . I move:
At end of motion, add:

'and (a) that clause 5 of the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1983 be referred to a Select Committee to inquire into and report upon the adequacy of the clause, particularly in relation to the overriding need to redress any financial disadvantage which might have been suffered by unsuspecting employees who were ostensibly the beneficiaries of a superannuation fund but were disadvantaged either by not being informed of their rights under the superannuation scheme or had their employment terminated in circumstances where they became disentitled to benefits from the fund;
(b) that provisions relating to membership, powers and proceedings of the Committee be contained in a subsequent Resolution.'.

I consider that this amendment is the logical outcome of all the arguments that have been advanced by the Government for the amendment contained in clause 5 of the Bill. Indeed, the wording of my amendment follows very closely the arguments that were advanced in the second reading speech and the words which were used by Senator Walsh in his speech in reply to Senator Chipp's motion. Quite obviously, if the Bill is enacted and the money goes into the Treasury, the ability of the funds to compensate the persons affected will be substantially reduced.

The question that the select committee would have to consider is what remedies are available to the employees concerned. One of the things that would need to be ascertained is how unsuspecting employees would be able to be advised of the fact that they were ostensibly beneficiaries of the superannuation fund. Clearly , the Commissioner of Taxation is in a position to ascertain the names of beneficiaries of a fund; in fact, under section 23F (2) (e) of the Income Tax Assessment Act the Commissioner is so informed. Furthermore, there appears to be a strong possibility that with the new lump sum taxation arrangements trustees will be required to deduct tax at source before paying a benefit. Therefore, trustees will be required to furnish regular returns to the Commissioner of Taxation, providing such details as names of beneficiaries, amounts, salary, date joined, service, et cetera.

The other aspect is the question of remedies available to the employees. Clearly, in New South Wales some limited remedies are available. The New South Wales Employment Protection Act of 1982 is relevant. Apart from compelling employers to give notice of and provide details of retrenchment, the New South Wales Employment Protection Act 1982 empowers the State Industrial Commission to order various kinds of severance payments to retrenched employees, including gratuities and superannuation payments above the normal entitlement. With regard to superannuation benefits, the Industrial Commission of New South Wales may make orders under the Act requiring, firstly, the payment of benefits from a superannuation scheme of which the employee is a member, as if the benefits ordered to be paid were provided by the scheme. That is contained in section 14 (1) (d) of the Employment Protection Act. It may require, secondly, the payment of an amount to the employee to compensate him for any loss of accrued benefits under a superannuation scheme of which he is a member. Section 14 (1) (e) of the Act refers to that.

As I said, there are limitations to this even in the New South Wales Employment Protection Act 1982. The limitations are that the employee would need to be aware of the fund's existence and of his entitlement under the scheme. That addresses the first matter that I mentioned, and it is one of the reasons why I wish to have such a select committee established. Of course the Act applies only to New South Wales awards. It also applies only where there are 15 employees or more. To my knowledge as yet no other States have similar legislation, although Victoria tried to bring down similar legislation but it was held up in the Legislative Council. I understand South Australia is also examining the possibility of such legislation.

The simple point I am making is that a select committee established by the Senate would be able to identify what might be available to affected employees and it could make recommendations which are more in keeping with the reasons that were advanced by the Government for clause 5 than in fact are contained in clause 5. I commend the amendment to the Senate and hope that it is carried. Incidentally, I propose to move a consequential amendment in the Committee stage and copies of that amendment have been distributed to honourable senators.

SPEAKING NOTES FOR ISSUES RAISED BY SENATOR HAMER DURING DEBATE ON INCOME TAX ASSESSMENT BILL (No. 5)
During the debate on this Bill, on 7 March, Senator Hamer sought two assurances regarding Australian shipping.

Firstly, he sought an assurance that a shipowner seeking taxation concessions would not be given concessions unless the total manpower costs for eligible ships have been brought down to reasonable world levels.

The proposed legislation seeks to build a nexus between lower capital costs available through concessions and lower operating costs. Crew numbers are a major determinant of total manpower costs and a reduction in manning will have a beneficial effect on the overall competitiveness of Australian ships.

A pre-requisite for granting of the taxation concessions contained in the proposed section 57AM is the issue of a manning notice by the Secretary, Department of Transport for the particular vessel. The manning notice specifies a number of officers and members of the crew of specified designations with which the ship should be manned to enable the ship to be operated in a safe and efficient manner. In determining the qualifying level, account is taken of manning levels and work practices on comparable ships operated by our international competitors. To be eligible for concessions the ship must not be manned at a level which exceeds that specified in the manning notice.

The Industry Task Force which examined the report of Sir John Crawford concluded that the adoption of the Crawford package, of which manning reductions and taxation concessions were central, would allow Australian ships to compete on similar terms with Australia's major trading partners.

Secondly, he sought assurance that under no circumstances would the Minister for Transport agree to give Australian ships a guaranteed proportion of our overseas trade, adding that if they were to get that guarantee they must do so by being competitive on the world shipping market. SPEECH.PARA: The third point, other than the contentious matter in this Bill, which has been referred to and which was raised by a number of people-most recently by Senator Harradine a few minutes ago-concerns the treatment by the Commissioner of Taxation of donations for bushfire relief or national disaster appeals made in cash or in kind. I am afraid I still do not have a reply from the Treasurer on that. I will seek to get one and provide it at some future time.

The main point of contention in this Bill is, of course, the provision which will collect revenue which has been avoided under what is known as the cherry- picker scheme. I will outline that in more detail later. That is a scheme under which employers pay employer contributions into what purports to be a superannuation fund for employees, but which is ultimately revealed to have been a device used to obtain deductions from taxable income for the employers, of which the employees frequently are unaware and from which they rarely receive any benefit. As I said, I will go into that in more detail. That is the contentious issue and notice has been given of a number of amendments relating to it.

As is customary in legislation designed to collect revenue from tax avoiders and tax dodgers, we have seen a great amount of cant, humbug and hypocrisy displayed by various speakers in this debate or, at best, at the most charitable , unawareness of the facts. Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle and Senator Hill both raised the question of why Part IVA and section 170 (8) of the Income Tax Assessment Act cannot be used against these schemes. This was also raised by Senator Archer by way of private correspondence to me. Part IVA can be used against paper schemes where there is a round robin of cheques passed around the same table or on the same day, but it cannot be effectively applied to the main stream cherry-picker schemes because the fraudulent nature of those schemes is not apparent at the time they are set up. The fraudulent nature of them becomes apparent only at a very much later stage when the employees are by some device or other, removed from the employ of the company prior to retirement date and therefore forfeit their entitlement under the superannuation fund. It is not possible to use Part IVA effectively to prevent the use of these schemes because the fraudulent nature of them is not and cannot be proven at the time the funds are established and at the time the contributions are paid in, with the possible limited exception of the last year in which the payments are made.

Similar limitations apply to section 170 (8) of the existing Act. Only in the last year can the Commissioner disallow entirely the deductions claimed by an employer for payments into this fund. For previous years in which deductions from taxable income may have been claimed by an employer, the Commissioner could disallow payments in excess of $400 per employee but could not disallow the statutory limit of $400 per employee. So section 170 (8) would be partially effective in dealing with these schemes, always providing there was some money left in the fund for the Commissioner to get at. I understand there are some cases where that is highly doubtful.

Senator Watson and Senator Messner attempted to drop the blame for the development and persistence of these schemes on to the Tax Commissioner, with the spurious claim that if the Commissioner had been exercising the rigid oversight of the operation of these schemes that he ought to have, the cherry pickers would never have been in a position to pick the cherries. Senator Watson and Senator Messner are thereby proposing that a regiment of people be added to the Australian Taxation Office to snoop around every existing superannuation fund, to interrogate or question employees on whether they have been properly notified in accordance with the provisions of the Act, and that sort of thing. I have two comments to make on that. Firstly, if the people who set up fraudulent schemes, or schemes which are ultimately revealed as being fraudulent, such as the cherry picker schemes, know that sooner or later they will have to pay the tax, they will not bother to set up the schemes. The way to get the message through to such people with total effectiveness is for the Senate to pass this legislation. Then every potential tax cheat will know that although in the short term he might be able to keep money that should have been paid in tax, in the long term he will have to pay the tax and the appropriate 20 per cent rate of interest between the time the tax should have been paid and the time it was actually paid. If, however, the Senate rejects this legislation, would-be perpetrators of any type of tax fraud scheme will receive the message from this House that they can set up such schemes, avoid income tax, and indeed not have to pay income tax ever, provided that they stop operating these schemes at the time Parliament passes some legislation.

The second point I make is about the proposition by two Opposition senators that the Taxation Office should employ a regiment of snoopers to police superannuation schemes, which I note as an aside yield almost no revenue because , by definition, they are tax exempt. It is a testimony to the audacity of Opposition members that when their Party was in government it ignored for years annual report after annual report from the Taxation Commissioner urging that more staff and facilities be provided to deal with tax avoidance. Those requests by the Commissioner were consistently ignored by the previous Government. A former Minister in that Government now has the audacity to put the blame on the Taxation Commissioner, who has had inadequate staff and who was starved of staff to pursue other sections of taxation law for many years. He has the audacity to suggest that the Commissioner should have used his already inadequate resources in attempting to police in the finest detail aspects of the taxation Act which did not yield revenue when he did not have sufficient staff to deal with those provisions of the Act that did yield revenue. Even if the Government were to follow the suggested route of adding on a regiment to the Taxation Office, that will not redress past frauds. There is no guarantee necessarily that it would prevent future frauds. The way to prevent future frauds against the revenue is for Parliament to pass this legislation. The way to give the green light to would-be tax avoiders of the future is for the Senate to amend this Bill in the way proposed by the Opposition or Senator Harradine.

The Senate has heard a lot of cant about justice for tax dodgers and tax avoiders. How about a little justice for honest taxpayers, the overwhelming majority of whom have met their obligations without devising and utilising notorious schemes such as the cherry picker scheme. Senator Harradine talked of justice to the employees of Raymor, about which I shall have something to say shortly. What about some justice for all the other business proprietors who did not indulge in tax avoidance but who were placed in a situation where they had to compete with less scrupulous firms which did indulge in tax avoidance? What about justice for all the honest pay as you earn taxpayers who for many years were forced to pay more tax than they ought to have done because companies such as Raymor, the Kelly brothers, an one or two chosen associates, were using loopholes in taxation law to avoid paying the tax they should have paid? Senator Townley said that it was dishonest to apply retrospective legislation, but apparently he accepts without equivocation the massive fraud on the revenue perpetrated by Raymor, of which I shall give details shortly.

Finally, there is a clear commitment under the prices and incomes accord reached last year between the Government and the Australian Council of Trade Unions, to stamp out tax avoidance schemes. The government, insofar as it is able, will honour that commitment under the prices and incomes accord. If we are prevented from doing that, that is to be regretted. If because of the capricious acts-I put it at best-by some honourable senators the Government is prevented from upholding that section of the accord and it is endangered, then economic recovery is endangered.

That brings me to the Raymor case, a case which finally got to court not because of its tax avoidance or dodging aspects but because the two chief perpetrators of the fraud, the Kelly brothers, subsequently fell out. One of them decided, as well as lining this pocket with what should have been paid in tax jointly by him and his brother, to appropriate the benefits entirely to himself. Consequently the case got to court and judgment was handed down by Mr Justice Wootten on 18 November 1982. The basis of the Raymor scheme followed the classic lines of all these cherry picker schemes. The owners of a company, who were also employees nominally of that company, set up what purported to be an employees' superannuation fund and claimed deductions from taxable income for payments made into that fund. The statutory limit of the amount that may be paid into such funds is $400 per employee, although that can be exceeded if the Commissioner allows. Apparently, it was not exceeded in the Kelly case. The employees notionally are to receive benefits on reaching retirement age, and only on reaching retirement age. If the employees terminate their employment with the company before reaching normal retirement age, the trust deed is set up so that the benefits go to other employees of the company. In the case of Raymor only one such employee, other than the Kellys themselves probably, received such a benefit or actually got any money.

In the five years ended June 1977 some two and three quarter million dollars was paid into the Raymor fund, at which time it reached the limit at which further contributions ceased to attract taxation advantages. The two and three quarter million dollars paid into the fund, according to the evidence of the Kelly brothers themselves, the effective owners and controllers of the company, was claimed as deduction from corporate income for tax purposes in the year in which it was paid into the fund. After June 1977 most of the money in the fund was then lent to the company at interest rates of between 2.7 per cent and 4.4 per cent. Mr Justice Wootten found that if money had been lent at the market rate as distinct from the concessional rate to the company itself, another $800, 000 or thereabouts would have accrued to the fund.

All the employees of the company had a notional entitlement to receive superannuation benefits on reaching normal retirement age. Mr Justice Wootten's judgment, which has been circulated to all senators, makes it very clear that the Kellys went to extraordinary lengths to ensure that employees did not reach retirement age. Mr Justice Wootten said in his judgment:

. . . in 1980 there were three employees who were within a month of reaching retiring age. And what happened to each of them is instructive. Mr Mitchell was due to reach the retiring age of 65 on 11 March 1980. His supervisor asked him if he would mind leaving on 27 February, and he said that it did not make any difference to him, and he left.
He was asked to leave 13 days-it was a leap year-before his normal retirement age. He said it did not make any difference to him and that he would leave. Mr Justice Wootten continued:
. . . unknown to him it made a difference of $48,000, the sum credited to him in the books of the fund, for which his employer had obtained taxation deductions.

Mrs Lowndes was due to reach retiring age on 15 July 1980. At the end of June her employment was terminated on a Friday on the pretext that staff had to be kept down, and that as a married woman she was the obvious person to go. Nevertheless, she was re-employed as a casual on the following Monday . . .

Is any more convincing evidence required of the blatant and contrived manner in which this fund was manipulated? It was not possible for the Commissioner of Taxation to determine at the time the fund was established in 1973 that it was established for essentially fraudulent purposes, for the purpose of defrauding the revenue. That was the purpose for which that fund was established, but it was not possible for the Commissioner at that time to determine that. But I doubt whether even the most gung ho apologist on the other side of the chamber for tax evaders would deny that what happened, particularly in the case of Mrs Lowndes, demonstrates the essentially fraudulent purpose of that fund. Mr Justice Wootten said:
. . . she was re-employed as a casual on the following Monday and was still working when the case came on for hearing before me.

Other examples are given of similar blatant manipulation of the fund for the clear purpose of defrauding the revenue. I refer anyone who may think that that interpretation is over-vigorous to page 600 of Mr Justice Wootten's judgment. On page 600 he quotes Mr Paul Kelly, the Kelly brother who brought the action against the other Kelly brother who tried to appropriate all the money for his personal benefit instead of splitting it principally with his brother, as was the original intention. Mr Paul Kelly said that if the court allowed his brother to keep the money:

. . . the court would be lending assistance to a blatant tax avoidance device to permit the trustee and the employers to have the advantage both of a trust deed which on its fact renders contributions tax deductible and also of an understanding between them that destroys the very basis upon which social policy allows tax deductions for contributions.

The defendant, Mr William Kelly, said in his reply that the type of fund established was 'by no means unusual', so called 'tax avoidance funds' being ' quite well-known'. I repeat: Could anything be more blatant or contrived? I submit that there is a clear, unassailable prima facie case that as a result of the manipulation of this fund the Kelly brothers, together with one or two favourite employees-but for practical purposes the Kelly brothers-have deprived the Commonwealth revenue of more than $1m over the period they operated it. The people who are opposing clause 5 of this Bill propose to ensure that the Kelly brothers are allowed to keep that ill-gotten gains. Senator Harradine professed a concern for the employees of the fund who were deprived of an entitlement because of the way in which it was manipulated by the Kelly brothers. One could make many points in response to that. I make two, not necessarily in order of importance. The employees themselves were not aware of the existence of a benefit; on those grounds, they had no expectations. It would have been for them a windfall gain if the benefit to which they were notionally entitled had been received. They had no knowledge of it and therefore no expectations. Therefore, it would have been in the category of a windfall gain.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you saying they therefore have no entitlement?

—That is perfectly correct. I underestimated Senator Harradine's ingenuity. We know, of course, that in 1982 when retrospective legislation was introduced by the previous government and his vote was not crucial to its passage, he voted for it. When retrospective tax legislation was introduced by this Government and his vote was crucial to its passage, he voted against it. I wondered how he was going to get out of this one. I thought he would be stuck, but he has demonstrated that he has more ingenuity than I thought. He is doing what he has consistently done; that is, he is using his vote in this Senate when it is crucial to protect tax dodgers and to allow them to keep their ill-gotten gains. SPEECH.PARA: The amendment in the first place proposes to refer to a select committee the question of whether it is possible in any way to use the taxation law to ensure that employees get benefits from a superannuation fund to which, according to strict legal interpretation of the trust deeds of that fund, they have no entitlement. The essential nature of Senator Harradine's manoeuvre this afternoon is as fraudulent as the scheme set up by Raymor and the Kelly brothers to pick cherries.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is wrong with the amendment?

An indication of the fraudulent intent of that amendment is the fact that not one hour ago the honourable senator dropped something in this Senate which requires quite complex legal examination. That is what the honourable senator proposes to do. The Government will oppose all the amendments which have been suggested. The effect of the amendments proposed by the Opposition is to remove the retrospectivity aspect of the Bill. It will be recalled that the Bill relates to a date, 1 July 1977. Despite the advice that has been given to us by the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh) throughout the debate, we are not of the opinion that we would support retrospectivity in the Bill in the way in which it has been inserted. Despite Senator Walsh's remarks with regard to prospectivity, I am able to say that the Opposition is prepared to support, prospectively, the provisions of the Bill with regard to employee superannuation funds but that we have very great difficulty with regard to the application of those provisions to a date in 1977.

I refer to one or two other points by the Minister in closing the second reading debate. He quoted one case at great length and in great detail. I wonder why, under income tax ruling 294 which requires an auditor's certificate, it is not further protection to the Commissioner of Taxation that at all times the fund is conducted in accordance with the requirements and that it complies fully with all the requirements of section 23F. In the ruling by the Commissioner there is a requirement that, every year in the case of a loan back fund and every three years in the case of other funds, a certificate be supplied by an independent auditor verifying that the assets of the fund actually exist in the fund, that they are in a form suitable for the purposes for which they exist and , in the event of the retirement or resignation of employees, the assets are readily realisable. It is also to be indicated whether, in the opinion of the auditor, the fund is being conducted in accordance with its constituent documents. That is a clear requirement under the income tax ruling.

It seems to me that the aim of the Taxation Office is to determine those funds which do not meet the requirements of section 23F and deal with them accordingly . The auditor will be commenting on the test which is set out in section 23F(2). If there were a qualified audit of any aspect of those requirements, the Commissioner of Taxation would treat the fund as a fund other than a fund meeting the requirements of section 23F, that is, a section 121DA fund. Such funds do not qualify for any special tax treatment. I presume that the Minister will say that he can only do that in a particular way. It seems to me that, in setting up a long term fund, if there is an annual requirement for an audit certificate giving those details, the Commission, at any time, has the protection of section 23F to determine for himself, retrospectively, whether the fund meets those requirements. One case has been mentioned at great length to support the introduction of the requirements backdated to 1977. However, that seems to us not to be justified. The Commissioner could determine whether the arrangements that were made under such funds worked against the provisions of section 23F. He could determine whether the conditions had been compiled with, that this fund was not exempt and, if it is terminated and justification is not given for the way in which it is being dealt with by the employers concerned, the Taxation Commissioner has his own powers under his own Act. His discretion may be exercised.

It seems to us to be an unnecessary provision to go back to 1977 without more evidence being given by the Minister other than that of the Kelly case which he has quoted in great detail. We have talked about the provisions during the second reading debate and maybe we will talk about them further today. They are very precise under this section of the Income Tax Assessment Act. They are for particular purposes. They must be compiled with continually in the opinion and the discretion of the Commission. There must be an audit certificate. In support of Opposition's amendment to remove the retrospectivity clause, I indicate that if the numbers in the Senate mean that our amendment prevails or if the clause is amended in some other way at any time that is appropriate we will deal expeditiously with prospective amendments such as the Commissioner feels he requires.
