I cannot say whether the message has got through--
This is the relevant response. He said:

I am a special prosecutor dealing with one particular matter. But I did notice, I think last week, in the 'Financial Review' that the Taxation Commissioner in justifying some retrospective legislation described the scheme, which was to do with superannuation, in terms which, if he was correct in his description, would have amounted to a fraud on the Commonwealth.
He continued:
I do not know whether he has referred that to the Attorney-General's Department or whether it has responded. It would be interesting to know.

Indeed, I am interested to know. I would like to know whether frauds of the type described by the Government have been referred to the Attorney-General's Department for consideration under section 231 of the Income Tax Assessment Act and whether there is some explanation for the long period of disuse into which section 231 has fallen. I am told that it has not been tested in the court since 1947. On the face of it to an ordinary reader like myself it would appear to provide a reasonable statutory basis for attacking fraudulent avoidance of tax that is said to have occurred and, undoubtedly, has occurred in relation to superannuation schemes. I simply ask whether, for example, the Kelly brothers case has been referred for the purpose of prosecution under section 231.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak briefly in support of the comments made by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle. From the very beginning of this debate I have asked now many cases we are concerned with. The only case that continually is mentioned is the decision of, I think, Mr Justice Wootten. It has been repeatedly mentioned and no one on this side of the chamber has in any way attempted to condone the factual situation in that case. On its facts it was an obnoxious affair. We would not seek in any way to condone the carrying on of superannuation business of that nature but, as we also all know, hard cases make bad laws. As far as we have been informed, that case is the total basis for this legislation. That is of particular concern to me. I will look at the type of cases with which we are told we are dealing. I think that tends to reinforce the one specific example that has been given. I will take the Committee back to the second reading speech delivered by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) which stated:

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment is directed against a particularly distasteful tax avoidance practice containing-
these are the critical words-
clear elements of fraud against both the revenue and unsuspecting employees.

As the debate proceeded we found further use of the same type of language in justifying this legislation. Put into the transcript was a letter from the Treasurer to Senator Walsh regarding the matter. Again, the same language appears. Speaking of the scheme he said:
Not only are they of a most blatant kind, but they contain elements of fraud against employees . . .

In the transcript also is a letter addressed to the Treasurer from Mr Boucher, the Acting Commissioner of Taxation, giving further information of the type of case that has caused a need for this legislation. I will read a couple of sentences from that letter which again uses a similar type of language:
That kind of thing involves clear elements of raids against the revenue and also against the unsuspecting ordinary employees concerned.
The letter continued:
The practices seem to me to be brazen and bare faced and involve abuses of the tax law . . .

Senator Chipp sought further information regarding the extent of these abuses and the amount of tax that had been lost. That is another question to which we still do not have an answer. We have been told how much revenue is expected to be obtained by the implementation of clause 5 but we have at no time been told what has been lost to the revenue. The Minister for Resources and Energy ( Senator Walsh) in his speech on 6 March said:
The schemes only became clearly fraudulent at the time they were wound up or at the time that various devices were employed to defraud the employees . . .
Again, he spoke of fraud. He continued to speak of the disgorgement of benefit from those funds in an improper way. He said:
A way which the employees of the company, for whose benefit ostensibly the fund was established, are deprived of their entitlements . . .
A little further down on page 486 of the transcript of that day, he said:

These are artificial, contrived, blatant schemes, the intent of which was at all times to defraud the Taxation Commissioner of revenue . . . It is that fraudulent intent by the managers of these funds which this legislation sets out to correct.

I think that is clear evidence that what we are being told we are dealing with in this matter is cases of fraud against the revenue and possibly fraud against certain employees. As I said when I commenced, one specific factual circumstance has been put to us that could be described as most improper with all usages of that word. That is the position we are told we are to address.

The point I made in my speech on the second reading was that the net has been cast far wider than that. The net has not only been cast but also is now to be backdated to 1977. It can entrap many people who gained an excess benefit in quite innocent circumstances. Senator Chipp received certain assurances from the Australian Taxation Office that it would not implement the provision except in extreme circumstances. I suggest to the Senate that that is a totally unsatisfactory way in which we should be imposing taxation laws. The Commissioner of Taxation, apparently has to make an interpretation on whether there are blatant contrived circumstances and then to apply this provision. If he does not think there are blatant contrived circumstances he will not apply it . The Minister will say that even if he does apply it the taxpayer, under a provision in the Bill, can go back to the Commissioner and ask him not to exercise his discretion in that way. But, as I said in my speech on the second reading, no clear guidelines are given as to the basis upon which the Commissioner is to act or upon which the taxpayer has the right to have his matter determined. This is totally unsatisfactory tax law.

I turn back to the fraudulent case which we are told justifies the provision and our particular concern as to why the Commissioner and the Government are not utilising provisions that already exist to remedy the situation. It remains my view, notwithstanding what the Minister said today, that there are adequate provisions within the Income Tax Assessment Act and the Commonwealth Crimes Act to deal adequately with the problem of fraud. Today the Minister gave us an interpretation of Part IVA of the Act. I think that that interpretation and its narrowness will amaze tax experts throughout Australia. I am sure that most honourable senators here were surprised, to say the least, as to the extremely narrow interpretation that this Government apparently wishes to place upon Part IVA of the Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —They were wrong on the Acts Interpretation Act last time, so they are probably wrong this time.

—With the greatest respect to the Minister, I suspect that he is wrong in this case. The Minister did not mention the potential for using section 260 of the Act, which is still in force and has a wide application. Perhaps the question should again be asked: Why has the Commissioner not used that provision in the past? The Minister mentioned section 170 of the Act but again I think his interpretation is open to question.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to raise the matters which were mentioned by Senator Tate, namely, the matters that were put to the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs by the Special Prosecutor, Mr Gyles, QC, who looked at bottom of the harbour taxation cases. I will not quote from the transcript as Senator Tate has just put the matter before the Senate. Regarding bottom of the harbour taxation schemes, Senator Tate asked why the Commissioner of Taxation and the Government have not used section 231 of the Income Tax Assessment Act. We have not yet received an answer to that question. I hope that we will get it from the Minister during our consideration of the Bill. Senator Tate asked why section 86 of the Commonwealth Crimes Act, which is the provision dealing with conspiracy to fraud-in most of these cases there was a conspiracy-had not been used. He said he was amazed that these provisions were not used in the bottom of the harbour cases. Senator Tate said that in the media he had noticed reference to this legislation regarding superannuation and attempts to make it retrospective to 1977. Again, he asked the same question: Why have these provisions, which have existed for so long in our legislation, not been implemented? These questions remain.

What we are asked to do today is to pass legislation which I suspect, on most interpretations of the law, is unnecessary. I suspect that there are adequate powers in the Income Tax Assessment Act and the Crimes Act to ensure that fraudulent cases are adequately dealt with and that the cherry-picking scheme, as it has been referred to, is wiped out without any need for this legislation. If that is correct then the justification to back-date the legislation to 1977 and make it retrospective for so many years is even more difficult to understand . As I said, I support the points which Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle put to the Committee. We believe this provision is bad law. Retrospectivity should not be supported in any way. As I indicated, I suspect that, even without the retrospectivity aspect, this legislation is totally unnecessary to achieve the purposes the Government seeks.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Minister, Senator Walsh, has put forward clause 5 knowing full well that it contains a retrospective element that is not acceptable to the Committee. In rejecting out of hand the amendment that I proposed at the second reading stage of the Bill, he has telegraphed the intention of the Government blindly to levy retrospective taxes at any price, even the rights of employees involved. I remind the Committee that had my amendment been adopted I would have moved a consequential amendment to this clause. Senator Walsh, in referring to that consequential amendment, said that the amendment meant that not only would the managers of the superannuation funds or the superannuation funds be able to have levied from them certain taxes retrospectively but also they would not be able to have those taxes levied prospectively. I rose to put the Minister on the right train, but I was not in order at that stage. Anybody reading this would see that what Senator Walsh said was, as usual, incorrect. I will leave to another stage the biggest blunder that he has made on these issues last year, but it is coming to him. The Minister said that he had received the advice from the Taxation Office, which, again, is a real clanger.
—You got exactly the same advice.
—Yes, I heard correctly. Apparently the Minister did not. The proposed amendment stated:

SPEECH.PARA: At any stage after this Act receives Royal Assent, both Houses of Parliament may pass a Resolution specifying a day on which section 5 shall come into operation.
The amendment continued:
Section 5 shall come into operation on the day specified in a Resolution agreed to by both Houses of Parliament in accordance with sub-section 2 (2).

The reason for that was to enable the select committee to do its work and report to the Parliament. Depending on what that report said, or irrespective of what that report said, at any stage after the Act received royal assent, both Houses of Parliament could have moved a motion specifying the date on which section 5 came into effect. That could have been either retrospectively or prospectively. Senator Walsh's statement at the second reading stage again misled the Parliament. We will come to the crunch one day when we deal with the new Acts Interpretation Act, the extrinsic aids and the interpretation of the law. If Senator Walsh carries on the way he is going and misleads the Parliament almost every time he stands up, the poor old judges will have their work cut out if and when we pass that legislation. The other aspect I raise is that clearly anybody would realise that Senator Walsh did not address himself to the amendment. He said that the employees concerned had no entitlement.

TALK.START.PARA: —And more-until they reached normal retiring age.
—But what did the Minister say on 6 March 1984? The Minister quoted from the Taxation Commissioner's letter. Page 485 of Hansard states:

SPEECH.PARA: The letter goes on to state that what then happens is that the employees who are ostensibly the beneficiaries of the fund are in one way or another deprived of their entitlement.

Mr Chairman, as I indicated at the second reading stage, I thought in quite some detail because a good deal of work has been done on this matter, at least one statute in place in Australia-it presumably covers the bulk of the workers in the biggest State of Australia-could conceivably be utilised to ensure that some recompense is provided to employees who have been used in respect of these schemes. I refer to the Employment Protection Act of 1982. That Act says quite specifically that, in regard to superannuation benefits, the Industrial Commission may make a number of orders. The orders need not be orders strictly applying the terms of the fund. The Act says:

The Commission may make orders under the Act requiring the payment of benefits from a superannuation scheme of which the employee is a member as if the benefits ordered to be paid were provided by the scheme.

We are always talking about deeming provisions in these pieces of tax legislation, and there is a deeming provision there. I am sorry that my proposal was not adopted because had it been agreed to I would have made myself available to be on the committee and I would have been very hopeful that the committee would have been able to unearth the details of a number of these schemes and do what I thought was proposed in the Minister's second reading speech-that is to say, redress the wrong done to employees. That is why I said in my amendment that we ought to establish not the primacy of the Australian Taxation Office, as this legislation is doing, but the overriding need to redress any financial disadvantage which might have been suffered by unsuspecting employees who were ostensibly the beneficiaries of a superannuation fund.

Senator Walsh did not address himself to why that select committee should not be established, why the facts cannot be unearthed. He is acting in the same way as he acted on a previous occasion, in respect of the bottom of the harbour legislation. Honourable senators will recall that the proposal for a committee to unearth that bottom of the harbour problem was rejected. Instead of addressing himself to the essence of the amendment, he tried his usual vilification stunt. That did not work, so he called, of all things, on the Australian Council of Trade Unions' prices and incomes accord, to deny the opportunity of employees who have suffered disadvantage to seek redress. That did not work, so he said that I did not give him enough time. Again he is wrong because on 6 March 1984 I said in this chamber, in his presence, that I would be seeking to draft an amendment to do precisely what I have proposed in my amendment. It is all there on pages 486 to 487 of Hansard of 6 March. Ample notice was given, and given formally to the Senate. At the conclusion of my statement on that occasion, I said:
Therefore, I will now have to retire and consider what will be the appropriate amendment to the second reading motion so as to ensure that the workers get something, and not just the Taxation Office.

And Senator Walsh says that no notice was given! Clearly, my amendment sought to have the Senate establish the overriding need to redress any financial disadvantage suffered by employees for whose benefit the schemes were ostensibly established. Maybe this is possible and maybe it is not. I suspect that in some cases it will be possible and in some cases it will not, but the Government is proposing to pass this Bill and give priority to the Taxation Office, and to do it retrospectively. I say quite bluntly and openly that, in rejecting this move, Senator Walsh has telegraphed his intention to pressure the Government into blindly levying retrospective taxes at any price, even at the cost of the rights of the employees concerned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to answer some of the propositions that have been put in this debate. The main concern of Senator Hill and Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle seems to have been that the Government has relied on only one case-the Kelly case-with the implication being that if others were produced we would assent. The argument runs that this is an isolated incident and bad law is made if we take one incident and legislate. I refer those honourable senators to my second reading speech in which I drew attention to at least one other case, a case in Newcastle. I also refer them to the decision in the Kelly case by Mr Justice Wootten in which he quoted approvingly- I do not have the actual decision in front of me-from the evidence of an expert witness, a person expert in superannuation funds.

SPEECH.PARA: His evidence to that hearing stressed that essentially there were two types of superannuation funds-the type meant legitimately and the type meant illegitimately as tax avoidance mechanisms. Those who move in the commercial world know that the evidence given by that expert witness did not refer just to that particular case but also to a practice that has been reasonably widespread in the small business sector. Of course, there are none so blind as they who will not see. Simply because a spectacular case has been mentioned in the Senate this does not mean that it is the only case. There is sufficient evidence around to establish that this provision is necessary to stamp out a practice that is, or has been, widespread and could become even worse.

The remarks to which I want to address myself most of all are those of the previous speaker, Senator Harradine. As I recall what he said in the debate previously, it was that he would remedy what he alleged was a defect in the legislation by bringing forward an amendment at this stage that would confer a benefit on the employees of the false schemes run in their names. As I recall it , that is what was said. The amendment before us confers nothing on any worker and cannot be said in any sense to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —It confers some benefit on the Kellys and others.

—Yes. I want to look at the logic of the Harradine proposal, which thankfully was defeated. It is farcical to pretend that it would have conferred a benefit on any worker, or would have been likely to confer a benefit on any worker. In saying that, I believe that we on the Government side are quite reasonably and properly suspicious of the real intention of the Harradine amendment, given the record of Senator Harradine in voting down all of the tax avoidance legislation that this Government has put forward. It seems to me that Senator Harradine's amendment was merely a device to justify yet again a voting down of an amendment to the Income Tax Assessment Act that will stamp out tax avoidance.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Harradine's first proposition was that we have a committee to redress any financial disadvantage which might have been suffered by unsuspecting employees who were ostensibly beneficiaries of a superannuation fund but who were disadvantaged by not being informed of their rights under the superannuation scheme, had their employment terminated, et cetera. I suppose that, were such a committee to be established, the first thing to be done would be to call all those people who did not know of their rights to come forward and give evidence. We cannot go past the point that the cherry-picker scheme operates on the fundamental principle that the rights of workers are not known by those workers or that their rights are obfuscated so that they have only a vague understanding of the scheme. That is how the cherry-picker scheme operates . How can we establish how widespread the practice is by asking workers to come forward and claim a right that they did not know, or know for sure, existed under the principle of the scheme?

The second proposition was that, if we were able to establish that cases existed, how would we address that? Do we confiscate all the moneys that were due and pay them back to the workers? I would have thought that that was a reasonable way of addressing the problems for the workers if we could identify the schemes and knew how extensive they were. How we would go about doing that is indeed an important question. It raises a plethora of problems, none of which , I argue, are capable of being answered in any conclusive way. They can be looked at only vaguely but not answered directly. As Senator Walsh has said, a principal way in which the cherry-picker scheme operates is for one company to transmit all of its responsibilities to another company but not transmit the payment of superannuation. Extensive amendments would be required to uncover such cases and such companies. How we would locate all such employees, since it has been a widespread practice in the past rather than a current practice, is another problem.

The logical way to proceed is, of course, to do what the Government proposes to do and require that legitimate taxes be paid. The legitimate taxes would be recovered. In that case legitimate superannuation schemes would be established. The problem with the cherry-picker scheme is that one cannot prospectively move against it because it becomes illegal only when it is wound up, when the workers are dismissed. During the running of the scheme it is not manifestly illegal. It becomes an avoidance mechanism only when the workers are dismissed or induced to leave. Of course, the principle of that scheme is to deny the rights of the workers by encouraging them to leave without their being aware of their entitlements. The fact that their employment is actually terminated means the severance of the employment contract and that the rights of the employees automatically and legally cease. What Senator Harradine's amendment aimed to do was to take on a task which bordered on the impossible and which would not solve the problem fully, directly or at all. Secondly, it contemplated the very thing that Senator Harradine has railed against in all of the legislation that we have brought forward previously, that is, a massive retrospective payout.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is right, to the workers.

—But only if one could identify those workers. Senator Harradine should bear in mind that those workers who did not know of their rights are required to indicate that they did not know. That is an impossibility. It is not the question of retrospectivity that Senator Harradine opposes. It is only the question of retrospectivity with respect to tax avoiders that he opposes.

SPEECH.PARA: The quickest way of demonstrating a real concern for the workers is to look at the official position that workers' organisations have put forward in this country. A key aspect of the prices and incomes accord with the Australian Council of Trade Unions is to wipe out tax avoidance. If anyone in this chamber wants to pretend to represent the interests of the workers, he had better explain, because it is not obvious to any worker in this country, why the provisions of the prices and incomes accord should be voted against on tax avoidance and it be pretended that it be in the best interests of the workers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elstob Sen R.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —After speaking on the Income Tax Assessment (Amendment) Bill (No. 5) 1983 some two and a half weeks ago, apparently a number of people heard what I said. Up till now eight people have been in touch with me. One person has fully documented what happened. He does not want his name revealed and I will honour that but I will name the firm concerned. I do not have documentation relating to the other firms at this stage . The cases refer to superannuation that should have been received but was not received. In this one instance, the person paid into the fund five and a half per cent of his salary. He was duped out of any moneys. He received only the amount that he paid in, plus 2 per cent. Much has been said by Senator Hill and Senator Harradine about this legislation. The terrible thing is that these schemes are legal. This is the terrible part. Employees sign up for a scheme which requires them to stay in that employment either for a certain number of years or until they reach a certain age in order to benefit from it, but the firms see that they do not stay for that time. The firm involved in the case of this individual is now known as Haden Engineering Pty Ltd, a commercial and industrial air-conditioning firm. If I recall correctly, it was formally known as Carrier Air Conditioning Pty Ltd. I have information about another seven firms which has amazed me.

SPEECH.PARA: This chap thought he was going to receive something like $80,000 but he got back only a couple of thousand dollars. I do not have the figures here. I did not bring all the details of the case with me. What the firm has done, in the true sense, is legal. How can the employees be paid back when they have been duped into going into these schemes? They were legal schemes but, unbeknown to the employees, if they did not serve the full term-15 years in this case or until a certain age-they had no legal right to receive anything out of the fund. This chap was not a member of top management; he was a sales manager in the firm . What can a person do if he gets the sack or becomes redundant at 55 years of age?

TALK.START.PARA: —Did he get the sack?
—Yes, he did, for no valid reason whatsoever. But this case goes even further because under this agreement he lost even his long service leave.
—He can't.

—The honourable senator says it cannot be done. I will show him and any other honourable senator how it can be done. It is documented here. He sent this to me late last week. The agreement was that the payments could be offset with long service leave. So he lost not only the amount that was rightfully his-the firm never intended to pay him anything on that-but also his long service leave. That was also written into the agreement. I do not want this man's name disclosed because he has asked that that not be done. I have checked whether the agreement is legal, and it is, so honourable senators should not say it is not. These people deliberately went out to rob the employees, who thought that they were going to receive a certain amount of money. This individual told me that he has never voted Labor in his life. He has been a Liberal voter all his life. He said: 'I can't understand what the Liberal Party has done to me'. This is what is going on. It is the most dishonest thing I have seen in my life. It is widespread; there is no doubt about that whatsoever. I will name the other companies which people have said they have been duped by: Dalgety, Kelvinator Australia Ltd and Email Ltd. All of those firms have been involved in such a scheme. All these people have been in touch with me in a short period.

SPEECH.PARA: Do not tell me those firms should not be fined and that money recovered. What they have done to people over many years is an absolute disgrace. It does not become known until the people are ready to receive the benefit that they thought they were going to get. That is the terrible part. Those firms have destroyed people's lives. That is what has to be considered. Another point I have made previously is that this is unfair to the honest firms that are trying to compete . If a firm dodges taxation by various means it has an unfair advantage over those which are paying taxes and being honest. They cannot compete. I think that is another aspect that all honourable senators should think about.

The terrible part is that it is impossible to pay this money back to the people who should have it. I agree with anyone here who says that if it is possible to pay it back it should be paid back, but these superannuation schemes were designed to ensure that the employee would never benefit. No one can convince me that these firms that have deliberately destroyed people's lives should not suffer a penalty. Any of us who thought we would receive a benefit at the age of 55 or 60 and who received virtually nothing would realise that. There is a range of schemes. A lot of them have had no money paid into them. It is impossible to pay these people back. Every person I spoke to went into these schemes believing them to be legal.

A lot of these schemes were carried out in conjunction with the Australian Mutual Provident Society. They were signed up with the AMP. It is all recorded. Everyone I have spoken to has said the schemes were designed by the AMP in conjuction with the firms. The top or three people in those firms are getting the plums out of the scheme. That is what is going on. What I am telling honourable senators is absolutely truthful. I can show them the case histories. They amazed me and they will amaze a lot of people. It is so widespread--

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you saying that AMP is involved in these schemes?
—AMP is involved, but not illegally.
—To get out of taxes?

—The schemes were written up by AMP but the benefits go to only a few people. AMP is not actually doing anything illegal that I can see. But the schemes were designed so that only a small number of people in these firms would get anything out of them. The firms have had tax concessions over the years. Nobody can convince me that these firms or individuals should not pay retrospective tax, having crippled people's lives. People who thought they were going to get a benefit have got nothing. Every case that has come to my notice involves an amount of between $50,000 and $90,000. All the people concerned, having put money into the schemes, finish up receiving under $3,000. In some cases it represents 3 1/2 per cent of what they put in. The case of the person in the employ of the air-conditioning firm got back 2 per cent of what he put in . I have a photostat copy of the cheque that was paid to him and everything else .
—Are you talking about 23F schemes?

—I am talking about the way the scheme has been designed to defraud people. It is not illegal; it is legally correct. But it is dishonest. The people are not informed about it. What I said in my speech about three weeks ago was that the information concerning the scheme is held in the general manager's office. If anyone wants to go into that office-I have heard cases of this happening-he or she is called a com., an agitator and everything else and is kicked out. That is what actually happens. This chap got a job in another firm after being unemployed for about 18 months. He does not want his name to be known because he fears that he will once again lose his job. I ask honourable senators to understand this human tragedy. All the crocodile tears about these firms not being required to pay retrospective tax are disgraceful. I think that the firms should be made to pay for what they have done to these individuals and their families. That will stop these totally dishonest schemes from continuing.
—They have been stopped.
—They have not been stopped. They are still going on. I reject the amendment. I do not believe in retrospective legislation generally, but where people are being deprived it is justified and right.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last year Senator Harradine used to make sanctimonious pronouncements about the sanctity of certainty before the law. Today he has presented the Committee with an amendment, which in the most nebulous terms almost three weeks ago he signified an intent to move and then produced less than three hours ago. That amendment, which originates from an honourable senator who used to sermonise about the need for certainty before the law, means that clause 5 of the Bill, if enacted, will not come into operation for the time being. It might come into operation at some stage in the future, after both Houses of Parliament have given assent. In the meantime, not only would people like the Kelly brothers be allowed to keep money which should properly have been paid in taxation many years ago, but would-be perpetrators of new cherry picker schemes, subject only to the uncertain constraints of section 260, section 341, section 170 (8) or Part IVA, would then be given the green light to continue to operate these schemes. So much for the sanctity of certainty before the law, which Senator Harradine upholds as a fundamental principle, when it is necessary to concoct some other apologia for his consistent record, when his vote counts, in voting down legislation in the Senate which seeks to recover money that should have been paid years ago by tax avoiders. Senator Harradine takes the view that if his amendment had been adopted-he believed in it so much he did not even bother to move the first one-then, in some way he is not able to explain, this Senator committee would have worked out how to transfer, through the taxation act, money to the employees who did not get money ostensibly paid into superannuation funds for their benefit.
—And did not know about it.

—Even though they did not know about it-I do not know about all cases, but certainly in a great number of cases they did not even know about it. It is argued that at some time in future the Senate will say that clause 5 will be operative from some date or other. After the proposed committee has conducted this hypothetical investigation, which could easily take the rest of this year, the proposition will then return to the Senate and the House of Representatives, to this effect: 'We will allow clause 5 to be operative at some date or other'. That is where the catch-22 comes in. People like Senator Harradine will say that we cannot apply the clause backdated even to 7 December 1983.
—Why not?

—Because people like Senator Harradine will raise spurious excuses for not doing it. He will say it if his vote is crucial. Other people like Senator Macklin and Senator Chipp have said it consistently. Senator Harradine says it when it suits him. The argument will then be put that it would not be right to proclaim clause 5 with a date operative from any date other than the date on which the proclamation motion is introduced into Parliament. It will be said by people like Senator Harradine, and some others who have a more consistent record on this matter than does Senator Harradine, that it would be morally indefensible to apply that clause retrospectively when for some years, and for perhaps another year hence, people have not been certain whether that clause would be proclaimed, and for what operational date it would be proclaimed . That is the proposition which has been introduced to the Committee tonight by Senator Harradine, who used to sermonise about the sanctity of certainty before the law. He believes so much in that proposition that he did not even bother to move the amendment. That shows how committed he is to it. This is a subterfuge. The additional factor is that if his amendments had been carried, there would have been no certainty that prospective operators of cherry picker schemes could have been stopped from setting them up and operating. The Commissioner would then have to fall back on other sections of the Act which cannot be guaranteed to work.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Harradine's next red herring was to mention the Employment Protection Act 1982, of which I confess I was previously unaware, which is apparently a statute of the State of New South Wales. He explained how that Act could be used to recover moneys to which employees had a nominal, though strictly speaking not a legal, entitlement under the deeds of trust. I shall not pass an opinion about an Act of which I was previously unaware, but I will state this with absolute certainty: Whatever potential that Act has to recover from the operators of the cherry picker schemes, the notional or presumed entitlements of workers still exist irrespective of what happens to this Bill. It is extraordinary, even for Senator Harradine, that he should name a statute of another parliament which, he says, gives the employees a right to recover the money and use that as an excuse to defer the proclamation of a clause in a Bill before this Parliament which gives the Taxation Commissioner the right to recover the tax which should have been paid years ago. The three amendments are all of a minor nature and deal with the short term life insurance provisions of the Bill. By way of background, the amendment proposed by clause 6 of the Bill removes the income tax advantages available to life insurance policy holders in respect of short term insurance arrangements. The provision gives effect, subject to an extension of the taxable period to 10 years for policies issued after 7 December 1983, to measures announced by the previous government on 27 August 1982. In announcing these measures, the then Treasurer proposed that bonuses or other proceeds paid under short term life insurance policies would become subject to tax, but only to the extent to which they exceeded premiums paid. It has been drawn to the Government's attention that the Bill as introduced may not fully achieve that in the case of traditional life insurance policies terminated within the extended taxable period. Where a policyholder terminates a traditional policy at a loss he or she may have participated in profits, by way of bonuses, and under the Bill be taxable on those profits.

Reflecting the variety of situations that may be encountered, the first amendment will overcome this unintended effect by providing that the Commissioner of Taxation may appropriately exclude from assessable income a part of a bonus which would otherwise fall to be taxed. The Commissioner is to have regard to such matters as total premiums paid on the policy, any amounts or bonuses previously received under the policy and the surrender value of the policy. In practice this will mean that bonuses will not be subject to tax under the new measures unless the total amount received by the holder or holders of a policy exceeds the premiums paid under the policy.

The second amendment will ensure that the short term life insurance measures specifically deal with the case where a policy holder decides to discontinue premium payments and applies for the issue of a paid-up policy in lieu of the original policy. Where a policy is, in effect, converted to a paid-up policy, it is not intended that any amount should, on conversion, fall to be taxed under the new measures. The amendment treats the paid-up policy for all purposes, including the ascertainment of the 10-year taxable period should the replacement policy itself be terminated early, as a continuation of the original policy. The third amendment relates to clause 25 which provides for a rebate of tax at the standard rate in respect of bonuses paid by a taxable life assurance company and which are, by virtue of clause 6, to be included in assessable income. The Bill as introduced does not cater for the case where a trust beneficiary or a partner has an amount included in his or her income as a result of the inclusion of an amount subject to the new measures in the assessable income of the trust or partnership. The amendment I propose will ensure that beneficiaries and partners in these circumstances are, as was intended, entitled to the rebate. I commend the amendments to the Committee. As far as I know, there will be not be any opposition to the amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Judiciary Amendment Bill which is before the Senate seeks to amend the Judiciary Act to provide a backup for Victorian legislation designed to enable in camera hearings to take place in relation to any charges which may be laid against the Australian Secret Intelligence Service agents who took part in the incident at the Sheraton Hotel. The effect of the Bill amending the Federal law is simply to provide that if a Victorian court makes an order a person who does not comply with it may be dealt with by the Federal Court. The Victorian legislation provides that the Attorney- General of the Commonwealth or the Attorney-General of Victoria may apply, if it is in the interests of national or international security, for an order that the whole or part of the proceedings may be held in a closed court in respect of any cases that may come before a Victorian court arising out of the ASIS incident.

SPEECH.PARA: The ASIS incident has been the subject of a good deal of comment both inside and outside the Parliament and I do not propose to go over the ground again. Suffice it to say that the agents of security services are not above the law, and the law must take its course against such people if they are in breach of it . That is a principle which the Opposition has made perfectly clear and which I repeat tonight. Certainly there were some disquieting aspects of the ASIS operation, and it has been the subject of a report by Mr Justice Hope, which was tabled in this Parliament a few weeks ago. As one has come to expect from Mr Justice Hope, the report contained very rational and careful findings in relation to the incident and made some very useful recommendations.

However, Mr Justice Hope obviously was concerned about the situation of the disclosure by the Commonwealth Government of the names of the ASIS agents. As I understand the position, some of the agents who took part in the exercise have been apprehended or summonsed and charges are to be or have been laid against them. The names of others who were associated with the exercise are not known to the Victorian Government but are known to the Commonwealth Government. Discussions have been going on between the respective governments about the disclosure of the names of those agents so that the Victorian Government presumably can make inquiries as to whether charges should be laid against those agents as well. On page 70 of Mr Justice Hope's report paragraph 6.6 states:

Special problems arise in relation to the disclosure of the names of the persons involved in the Sheraton Hotel incident which are the subject of additional considerations. During the course of my inquiry the Department of Foreign Affairs provided me with a statement about the consequences for foreign relations and national security of disclosure of the names. These are summarised in Appendix VI.
I might say that Appendix VI is a secret part of the report. Mr Justice Hope proceeds:
I am satisfied by the material in that statement that the disclosure of the names would be likely to have the consequences claimed by the Department.

In my opinion, these considerations are sufficient to warrant my recommending, as I do, that the names be not disclosed. In making this recommendation I am mindful, however, that the question of whether there are legitimate counterveiling considerations may come before the High Court for decision. I do not regard it as part of my function to attempt to resolve that issue.

It is a fact that proceedings have been commenced in the High Court of Australia on behalf of these ASIS agents and an interim injunction has been made preventing the disclosure of their names. No doubt those proceedings will go ahead if the agents involved are sufficiently concerned about their rights to pursue them. As far as we are concerned, that is a matter for determination by the High Court. Their rights should be protected by whatever legal redress is available to them.

However, apparently the Government has agreed that, as far as it is concerned, unless it is restrained permanently by the High Court from making the names available to the Victorian Court, it will do so. The Opposition expresses some concern about that decision. As I said, Mr Justice Hope has recommended that the names not be disclosed. Perhaps whether his recommendation extends simply to the names being made public or means that the names should remain confidential to the Commonwealth Government is somewhat ambiguous. Whichever interpretation is placed upon it, obviously Mr Justice Hope is very concerned about some of the national security implications of disclosure of the names. Also, as he said, he believes that both foreign relations and national security considerations are involved.

What if the Commonwealth Government persists in its policy of accommodating the Victorian Government and making the names available? That may not necessarily be for the purpose of conducting a trial because presumably the Victorian Government's legal advisers have to consider whether there is sufficient evidence to charge these people. At all events, there is that likelihood of a trial and certainly the purpose of the Victorian Government pressing for the names is so that the agents can be charged for what the Victorian Government obviously strongly feels are breaches of Victorian law. As I said, this matter is still subject to proceedings in the High Court and if orders are made permanent in the High Court, that may frustrate the Commonwealth Government's intention. If the Commonwealth Government is determined that the names be made available, and it is free to make them available, then it is most desirable that any proceedings which result from that disclosure be in closed court. The Opposition supports the Bill to that extent.

However, the original proposal of the Victorian Government in the legislation introduced in the Victorian Parliament and which is to be supported by corresponding amendments to the Judiciary Act in this Parliament was that there should be a power on the part of the Attorney-General of the Commonwealth or of a State to seek an order in any proceedings, in the interests of national or international security or the interests of the physical safety of the accused or a witness, to the effect that proceedings be held in closed court. Other consequential orders could be sought and made. The Opposition believes it is appropriate to legislate for the closing of a court or the holding of proceedings in camera if those criteria are satisfied. Legislation should not be passed by this Parliament in respect of one particular incident. That is our preferred course. We believe legislation should be passed in that form and not in the restricted form of the Bill now before us. Admittedly the Victorian legislation has been introduced-for all I know, it may well have been passed-in this restricted form despite the preferable form it took when first proposed. I believe this Parliament should not accommodate that restricted approach the Victorians have taken and should make that clear by moving a suitable amendment to the legislation before it.

The Opposition certainly has some reservations about what the Government is planning to do in relation to this matter and has the firm conviction that if names are disclosed and there are proceedings in Victoria those proceedings should be held in camera in the interests of, as Mr Justice Hope puts it, foreign relations and national security. We support the principle espoused in this legislation but we do not think that it should be simply restricted to the ASIS incident. It should have general application.

TALK.START.PARA: —Support by the Australian Democrats for the Judiciary Amendment Bill 1984-indeed, we do support it-in no way implies any support for or approval of the disgraceful and expensive events of late last year resulting from the Australian Secret Intelligence Service raid on the Sheraton Hotel. The most alarming disclosure from the point of view of the Australian public has been that concerning the cost of compensation and other costs associated with this unfortunate episode. While some statements from the Government have indicated that this sort of thing will never happen again, it is time we had something a little clearer from the Government on why and how it will not happen again. In other words, these statements have more or less expressed a pious, rather sanctimonious view that this sort of thing will not happen again in Australia but we are still waiting for concrete statements and decisions from the Government on how it proposes to control the Australian Secret Intelligence Service so that it will not carry out these actions. The Australian community is waiting for that kind of assurance from the Government. These sorts of things regularly happen in various countries. The Central Intelligence Agency in America went through a period when the most appalling situations regularly occurred. Each time that happened the government of the time said that it must never happen again. But, lo and behold, it did happen again. I am not at all satisified that the Government is taking sufficient control of the situation to ensure that the Australian community is not exposed to another Sheraton episode.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Democrats are also concerned about the idea of limiting disclosure in court cases of any kind. Indeed, I have had feedback from the public that many citizens are similarly concerned. I say to the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) that these citizens take a cynical and disillusioned view of the prospects of limitation in this case. In my experience and that of a considerable number of people with whom this has been discussed, including some people in the media who I suppose are normally cynical anyway, this is widely seen by the public as a kind of cover-up. The Attorney-General may have some difficulty in overcoming that impression. If he feels that it is important that it be overcome, he will have to make greater effort than he has made to date. On the whole, this is an honest and healthy response from the Australian public and the media. The most close and careful scrutiny should be applied to this episode . After all, secret trials have been part of the stock-in-trade of dictatorships and quasi-dictatorships throughout history. They are something that we should accept in this society only with the greatest of suspicion and with the utmost circumspection.

As a result of these considerations the Democrats have thought hard and long about supporting this Bill. Quite early in its drafting we proposed some amendments that would at least limit the extent to which these trials were held in complete obscurity and secrecy. As a result of negotiations our amendments were included in the Bill as printed and in fact comprise the penultimate section on page 3 under the heading 'Reports' which reads:

(1) Subject to sub-section (2) the Attorney-General of the Commonwealth shall, as soon as practicable after each 30 June, lay before each House of the Parliament a report setting out- (a) the number of proceedings in which, to his knowledge, orders referred to in sub-section 49 (1) were made during the year that ended on that date; and
(b) particulars of those proceedings, including particulars of the judgments.
(2) Sub-section (1) does not require the making of a report in terms that would be inconsistent with any order referred to in sub-section 49 (1).

As things stand in the Bill, which has now been limited to the ASIS incident, this may not seem important. But we feel it is very important as a principle and as a point that may apply in future legislation of this kind. If, indeed, there is to be this sort of secret trial, at least the Attorney-General of the time must report to the Parliament that there has been a secret trial and what the consequences of it were. If we do not have that, we could have a situation in which secret trials proliferated in this country, just as they did in fascist countries and as they do in Soviet Russia, without anyone knowing about them. While I do not consider that to be the intention of the Government, it is very important when we are making legislation not to leave loopholes that could be exploited in the future. In this matter the Australian Democrats considered also those people who work for ASIS, the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation and our secret organisations. A completely secret situation could militate against them. Indeed, a series of trials could well have been held against a whole group of people without the people of this country every being aware of it. As the Bill stands now, it makes that impossible.

We were also concerned at the scope of the original Bill which, no doubt unintentionally, would have permitted actions other than the Sheraton one, the ASIS one, to take place without public knowledge and in secret. I hasten to say that I do not know of any such cases and I do not suspect any. But, theoretically I suppose, it is possible that the Government has a whole row of such things ready to trundle up and we must at least guard against that possibility. The two-year period mentioned in clause 51, which stated that this part does not apply in relation to an order made later than 2 years after the commencement of the Criminal Proceedings Act 1984 of Victoria, would, if it had not been modified elsewhere, possibly have permitted the introduction of other cases of this kind that we may never have known about. This is not in airy-fairy land or just speculation. It has happened in other countries. Where these gaps occur in legislation it is only too possible for them to be exploited by perhaps opportunists in the bureaucracy when there is sufficient reason from their point of view to do so.

However, the alteration to the Bill to limit its operations strictly, to quote page 2, to 'the incident that occurred at the Sherton Hotel in Melbourne on the night of 30 November 1983 involving the Australian Secret Intelligence Service', was done at the request of the Australian Democrats because we believed it most important that this should be a one-off operation and that it would be absolutely intolerable to the Australian community and the Australian people that any Bill of this kind which had a general application should pass any House of this Parliament. The moment that we do that we are with Hitler, with Mussolini and with Stalin. If we create any kind of legislation which would allow that kind of situation to occur more than once and not in any specific area, we would be going down a very dangerous path indeed.

I understand, and I find it almost incredible, that the Liberal Party of Australia may indeed be contemplating some sort of amendment to remove this clause. I will be interested indeed in its reasons for doing so and for saying to the Australian community that it is prepared to bring forward an amendment which would indeed create a situation of secret trials in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Grow up.

—Senator Durack protests; perhaps I should not prejudge him. I beg his pardon and I hope that what I suspect is not true and that the Liberal Party is not intending to move an amendment of that kind. I will wait and see what happens in that regard.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Democrats, like all reasonable people, regret the need in the world for secret intelligence operations. But we are not so naive as to believe that any country can unilaterally opt out of them. One of the facts of life is that this kind of operation appears to be necessary. It is, one might say, basically a cancer on international society for which we pay very dearly indeed and from which, if we take the balance internationally, we obtain very little. It harms and damages the world; let us face that. It is bitter war of attrition between those organisations which at great public expense carry out a kind of junior war against each other which does not really achieve anything except the negation of their own efforts. If we want that kind of world, so be it, but we have to recognise the facts about it. What a stupid, inconsequential, dangerous and expensive undertaking it is to the world.

In this ASIS incident at the Sheraton Hotel we see how it can impact on the community at large with great expense, great trouble and great danger. The people who operate in this strange half-world of security apparently are trained to see themselves as above and beyond the law of the land. Any organisation that does that, for whatever reason, is doing something which is fundamentally damaging and dangerous to the society it is supposed to protect. Members of such organisations do it obviously, as this incident showed, with a total sense of irresponsibility, with no idea of their proper responsibilities to society and no idea that they have may have been placed there in a particularly sensitive and delicate role where certain responsibilities and obligations are required of them, or should be, by the Community. They are the first and most willing to laugh at and deride those responsibilities and make nothing of them. If they earn the contempt, dislike and scorn of society, as ASIS has in this matter, they richly deserve it. That lesson needs to be driven home again and again by the Government.

If we are to have this sort of security organisation, for God's sake let us not have in it a group of juveniles, a group of non-grown up people, who believe they can go into a hotel and smash up its doors without anybody knowing about it and without its becoming a matter for government and the Press. How incredibly juvenile that was. We need an organisation which is capable of doing this delicate and sensitive work with intelligence. That is what the word ' intelligence' is supposed to mean. We have not seen much intelligence from the Australian Secret Intelligence Service in this episode. That organisation should mediate and reflect on the fact that intelligence is part of its name and make sure that in future it uses its intelligence in whatever it does.

We have been given reasons for the anonymity of the defendants in this case, which we have accepted as good and sufficient. Obviously, I cannot mention them. Just as obviously we plainly cannot be absolutely sure, on our knowledge, that they are justified. However, our decision has been to accept those reasons and on that basis and on the basis of the Government's having accepted the change we proposed-I thank it for having done so-we support the Bill. I conclude by saying again to this House, to the Parliament and to the community: Do not trust these people. Do not trust this organisation. Regard it as something which, because of its very nature, requires the most constant and vigilant scrutiny by the community, the Attorney-General and the Parliament. I would have thought that the people engaged in this sort of security organisation would realise that in any decent and reasonable community they cannot have the wide open brief that they think they ought to have. They cannot be above and beyond the law and destroy and smash things up. They should accept that they operate within the most careful limits of scrutiny and supervision on the part of the Government. On that basis and on that basis only the Australian Democrats support this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This debate was proceeding on a responsible line until Senator Mason made his contribution. I inform Senator Mason, who is trying to interject, that the world is not a Sunday school.
—Now you are going to hear it from Senator MacGibbon.

—Yes, it is a real world out there and I think Senator Gareth Evans has some insight into the realities of the world after the Combe affair. If honourable senators remember, I supported the Attorney in the way that he stood up to some intemperate and uneducated criticism that came from other people in this place. I inform Senator Mason that the world is not a Sunday school and I think that Senator Durack's comments about growing up are very relevant to the honourable senator's views on this subject. None of us like the covert operations that intelligence agencies get into but we are here as legislators and we have to assume the responsibility as legislators for their actions. I have not resiled from the fact that there are nasty people out there in the world who are not out to do us any good, and regrettably we have to compete with them in this way.

SPEECH.PARA: I certainly cannot accept the views of Senator Mason about this organisation, describing its members as some sorts of cowboys operating utterly without reference to the laws or to decency. He says that we should not trust this organisation in any way at all. I do trust this organisation. I do not know what its operational directives are. I could make a guess at them. All I know is that when it has been investigated it has always had a favourable report, particularly from other international agencies in the field. I am of the view that I would trust its members, and I am rather proud of them from what I know. I certainly do not have the sneering view of them that Senator Mason has.

The particular point of the Judiciary Amendment Bill 1984 that I have difficulty with concerns the Federal Government transferring the names of seven operators to the Victorian Government. Five of the operators were caught and their names are known to the Victorian Government, but apparently 12 were involved and those other seven are going to have their names given to the Victorian Government to be taken for a secret trial. I do not like secret trials . Whatever the blame or wherever it lies in this matter I do not know whether the Government bungled it, whether the Minister responsible bungled it through lack of control or whether there was bungling within the Department; and I do not think we will be permitted to know. This matter has had a pretty fair airing and I personally do not see why we have to take those people to trial. It is true that security organisations do not operate outside the law. They have to comply with the law, but the convention is that if they are caught breaking the law, and their training is for them not to break the law in their home country, they go to trial and nothing is said about it and the public does not know that a security body has been involved.

I cannot say strongly enough how opposed I am to the Federal Government giving the names of those agents, who are not known, to any other government. This is not a personal criticism, let alone a political one, of the present Victorian Government. I would be opposed if the names were going to the Queensland Government, the Western Australian Government or the Tasmanian Government. I do not see how we can tolerate this with people whose lives are involved. They are the employees of the Commonwealth. They are entitled to the protection of their employer in this circumstance. I think there is a possibility, since they operate internationally, that their own lives and maybe the security of their families will be involved if their names are made public. I believe that the names would become public if they were tried before a court in a State, whatever the provisions of secrecy. I just do not see how one can guarantee 100 per cent security against the disclosure of their names, and if 100 per cent security cannot be guaranteed I do not want on my hands as a legislator the responsibility for the endangering of their lives. I have far more concern for the people I am responsible for than that.

As Senator Durack said, the legal position is that they are, under their contracts, entitled to protection by the High Court of Australia, and they have already sought and been granted an interim injunction to prevent the disclosure of their names. I come back to this point: I believe there is a real risk to their lives if their names are given to the Victorian Government. After all, two judges of the High Court in New South Wales have been murdered in the last couple of years, for reasons we do not know.

TALK.START.PARA: —Family Court.
—I am sorry. I apologise. It was the Family Court of Australia .
—Only one has been murdered, and one was blown up.

—That is right. One's house was blown up. I am sorry. We have the recommendations of Mr Justice Hope, who is the highest authority in the country on security matters. He has an involvement going back over quite a few years in the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation as well as the Australian Secret Intelligence Service and all security matters. He is a person whose reputation has not been attacked in any way for his judgment on these matters.

SPEECH.PARA: Clauses 6 (6) and 6 (7) make it very clear that he believes the names of these men or women should not be disclosed. It is interesting that he makes the point that following representations from the Department of Foreign Affairs, as well as for reasons of national security, the disclosure of the names should not be made. I do not know; maybe there are nationals from another country involved. One might speculate on that. But I am prepared to accept the judgment of Mr Justice Hope on this. Those of us on this side of the chamber cannot say strongly enough how concerned we are at this proposed course of action by the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-Mr Acting Deputy President, this is a straightforward measure, the substance of which was sufficiently explained in the second reading speech and the justification for which has not been, except perhaps by Senator MacGibbon, seriously questioned in the course of this short second reading debate. The Australian Secret Intelligence Service-Sheraton Hotel Affair was indefensible and it has not been defended by the Government at any stage. We do believe it appropriate that criminal proceedings be initiated by the appropriate jurisdiction, the State of Victoria, against those who in fact committed or were reasonably believed to have committed criminal offences.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government also believes that it is appropriate in a Federal system such as our own, where the principles of comity between the governments in that Federal system are supposed to apply, that where there is knowledge by one government in the system of the possible commission of criminal offences that knowledge should not be withheld by the government concerned and communication refused to another government in the system. I would have thought that Senator MacGibbon, the good federalist that he is, would have appreciated and accepted the general force of that principle and the pressure accordingly that I believe has been legitimately placed upon the Commonwealth by the State of Victoria to pass to it information relating to and relevant to the conduct of criminal proceedings against the persons believed to have committed offences.

There were overwhelming reasons, the details of which it has not been possible to publicise fully or explain, why the names of the persons in question should not have become public as the result of the operation of that criminal process. There are reasons of the kind articulated by Senator MacGibbon why the Commonwealth has been enormously reluctant to communicate the names that were not in the possession of the Victorian Government to that Government in the absence of guarantees of confidentiality in relation to those names. Now we have a situation, however, in which the Victorian Government, as a result of consultations and inter-governmental discussions, has enacted, put in place, legislation to, I believe very effectively, guarantee confidentiality, both in terms of the operation of the court proceedings themselves such as may transpire in terms of the suppression of publication and the capacity to close the court, but also in respect of the court records to deny access for any purpose to anyone to those records. That legislation passed the Victorian Parliament in the last few days and received the royal assent this morning. This legislation is complementary legislation, enacted by the Commonwealth to apply nationwide and to ensure that there cannot be publication north of the Murray outside the boundaries of the State of Victoria and any other jurisdiction. The confidentiality will apply nationally and, to the extent that our writ runs, internationally. I regard that as a sufficient safeguard of the interests of those concerned and of Australia's interest in preserving national security so far as security-sensitive operations and information are concerned.

The only matter that would appear to be in issue in this debate has been foreshadowed by Senator Durack and, I understand, will be the subject of a Committee stage amendment by him. It relates to the precise scope of the legislation, the matter in issue being whether the Bill will extend solely to proceedings arising out of the Sheraton affair on 30 November last year, or whether the confidentiality provisions are to be capable of general application in circumstances, whatever they may be, where a court seeks to make a confidentiality order based on considerations of national security or concern about the physical safety of parties to the proceedings or witnesses.

The Government has taken the view quite strongly, and it has been supported by the Democrats, that the legislation ought to have a limited life. That is not contested by the Opposition, which agrees with the sunset clause. The Government also believes that the legislation should have a limited scope and not be capable of operation, except in relation to proceedings arising out of the Sheraton affair. The Government believes that this is a reasonable provision and reflects the quite exceptional character of the circumstances in this particular case. It is terribly important to maintain the principles of open courts and open justice in this country. It is only in the most exceptional circumstances that that principle should be modified in any way. The Sheraton affair, we believe, was such an exceptional circumstance. Quite how exceptional it is unfortunately cannot be explained in terms of the national security implications without putting at risk the very matters sought by this legislation to be protected. But the Government believes, after careful consideration, that this is an exceptional circumstance and as such demands exceptional protections to ensure that the principle of open administration of justice is not breached any more than is strictly necessary to secure the bringing to finality of such proceedings as may be made arising out of this case.

I make the further point that this proposition I am advancing commended itself to the counterparts of Senator Durack and the Opposition in Victoria. There the reality was that the Opposition Liberals were unequivocal that they would not support any legislation of the kind here proposed, unless it was limited to the Sheraton episode. We have all heard about fissures in the Opposition; we have all heard of the inability of the Liberal Party in this country to get its collective act together. Here is living proof of that phenomenon at work. The Victorian Liberals and the national Liberals have been conspicuously unable to get their collective act together even in as straightforward and simple a piece of legislation as this. We have an example of the kind of division that has reduced the Liberal Party, I am afraid, to a condition of real ineffectuality around the nation because of an utter failure to appreciate the policy significance of what it is doing and to act in a consistent and coherent way.

The truth of the matter is that a principle which commended itself to the Victorian Liberal Party and which has been accepted by the Victorian Government, and now by the Commonwealth Government, has shown itself to be utterly unacceptable to the Federal Opposition. In those circumstances one can only lament the inability of the Liberal Party to appreciate collectively as a national entity the basic principles that are here at stake. No doubt there will be more said about this at the Committee stage. Any further comments I might have to make on this particular issue will be reserved until then. I note the general support around the chamber for this measure. I appreciate that support and commend the Bill at the second reading stage to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 2, clause 3, proposed section 46, definition of 'proceedings', line 5, leave out all words after 'proceedings' (second occurring).

This is a very simple amendment which seeks to delete from the definition of ' proceedings' in clause 3 the specific reference to proceedings arising out of the Australian Security Intelligence Service incident at the Sheraton Hotel. The Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) was not in the chamber when I referred to this proposed amendment in my speech on the second reading. I hope to be spared more crocodile tears flowing from his eyes about this matter. The fact is that he himself in his second reading speech presented sound precedents for orders of this kind in legislation of both this country and the United Kingdom. The Minister quoted the United Kingdom Official Secrets Act. Senator Mason had a little more understanding of the nature of security, both international and national. He would know that some of the major treason trials in the United Kingdom in recent years-cases such as Blake-have been held in secret for the most elementary and obvious reasons which I am sure commend themselves to the Attorney-General. For example, there is the Commonwealth Crimes Act, of which, for the information of Senator Mason, I shall read section 85B:

At any time before or during the hearing before a Federal court, a court exercising Federal jurisdiction or a court of a Territory of an application or other proceedings, whether in pursuance of this Act or otherwise, the Judge or Magistrate, or other person presiding or competent to preside over the proceedings, may, if satisfied that such a course is expedient in the interest of the defence of the Commonwealth- (a) order that some or all of the members of the public shall be excluded during the whole or a part of the hearing of the application or proceedings;

or make other consequential orders. Those are similar to the proposals in the Victorian Bill. Senator Evans also mentioned provisions of the Federal Court of Australia Act. There is nothing in this proposal which is peculiar. Indeed, there are very sound precedents and very sound reasons for it. If we have secret organisations, in which I understand Senator Mason says he believes, regrettably there are occasions when the laws have to be modified to accommodate and preserve the secrecy of an organisation or of those who are employed by it and who, indeed, in many cases make quite considerable sacrifices in order to perform the public duty and service which membership of such organisations entails. People seem to get on their high horses about the membership of secret organisations. I do not include the Attorney-General in that category because he understands and supports the need for secrecy. However, some people in this chamber and outside it seem to make a profession these days of pouring scorn on those who devote their working lives, at some great sacrifice and risk on many occasions, to the performance of their public duties. If these people, as a result of their employment, find themselves in the public eye, as in this case, they should be protected. That protection should not apply only to this one particular incident. It may arise in other cases.

This Bill has a sunset clause. Sunset clauses seem to be in fashion with other groups these days, and I do not object to that. If the Government wants to put in a sunset clause, so be it. Nevertheless, I reiterate my view that this is a perfectly sound principle. The Victorian legislation is limited quite specifically, as is the Crimes Act, to matters such as the defence of the Commonwealth, security interests, or the protection from physical harm of a person in a court or a witness. I would have thought that the protection of a person from physical harm was a very sound principle and may even have commended itself to the Australian Democrats, but apparently it does not.

For all those reasons the Opposition has moved this amendment which, when all is said and done, only restores this Bill to the original form that was unveiled by the Government. Admittedly, it was not introduced into this chamber in that form, but the Victorian legislation had been introduced in that form and it was intended to introduce it in that form in this chamber. It may well be that the amendments were made because the Liberal members of the Victorian Parliament wanted it restricted. However, the fact is that the form we are now seeking to restore represents a perfectly justifiable and proper principle. It is the view of the Opposition that that principle should be affirmed, and that is the purpose of the amendment before the Chair.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Durack made the point, and I think he believes it quite sincerely, that it is for the protection of the operatives that there should be this kind of secrecy.
