DEBATE.TITLE: SHIPPING REGISTRATION AMENDMENT BILL 1984PROTECTION OF THE SEA (SHIPPING LEVY) AMENDMENT BILL 1984

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 6 March, on motion by Senator Grimes:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Shipping Registration Amendment Bill 1984 and the Protection of the Sea (Shipping Levy) Amendment Bill 1984 are allied Bills. The Opposition supports the passage of both Bills. The original legislation was introduced into the Parliament to overcome a historical situation. We were subject not to Australian shipping registration but to British legislation. This was one of the last vestiges of colonialism. It was not until 1982 that the registration of ships in this country was subject to Australian law.

SPEECH.PARA: There now has been some experience with the legislation that was introduced by the previous Government. The net result is that a number of improvements are now being made to the legislation. We applied the introduction of the legislation to make more workable the Act which was intended to facilitate shipping registration in this country and the total operation of shipping law. I remember as an articled clerk having some problems with learning the special rules that existed in relation to the registration of ship mortgages because we were subject to British legislation and there were all sorts of special things that articled clerks had to be taught in relation to them. I am sure that everyone will be pleased that we have now reached the stage of decolonisation where we are able to have our own legislation.

Among the principal changes that are now proposed is an increase in the number of Australian ships which are exempt from the requirement to register. These ships will still be able to register voluntarily but the requirements relating to commercial ships measuring 12 metres or more in length will be extended to those measuring 24 metres or more in length. That will mean the cost of registration will not be imposed upon the quite significant number of smaller commercial vessels operating in Australian waters. One important point to bear in mind is that pleasure craft are required to be registered before proceeding overseas. As someone with an interest in yachting and private sailing, I know of a number of people who have found, to their surprise, that registration was required for their boats. That has interfered with their plans for departure. The fact that registration is required does bear mention in this debate. If one is only going in one of the increasingly popular races from New South Wales or Queensland, usually from Sydney or Mooloolaba, to one of the south-west Pacific islands one should ensure that registration of one's boat has been effected.

Another provision is the improvement of the system in relation to ship mortgages. As I mentioned, I found when I was an articled clerk that the registration of ship mortgages was slightly complex. It has been improved as a result of the new legislation, but it is important in financial terms in relation to the maritime industry that financiers should not find difficulty in making the arrangements necessary for the provision of finance. The facilitation of that is something which I would applaud. I have no doubt that these amendments will improve the degree of confidence with which financiers provide finance for shipping. Whilst it is usually no problem to the major shipping lines, it can sometimes be a problem for some of the smaller operations. I applaud the fact that the amendments are being made.

Also included in the legislation is the provision relating to caveats. Caveats are well known in relation to titles to land. They are simply a beware notice indicating that someone has a claim and that before anybody conducts any transaction in relation to that land-in this case, in relation to a ship- inquiries should be made about the person who has lodged the caveat. Again that encourages confidence in relation to transactions with regard to ships and is an improvement which I believe will be of use. I have noticed that there are also to be changes to the tonnage length of ships as opposed to the overall length although, with regard to small ships, there is a definition of overall length and a new concept of tonnage length has been introduced and is determined in accordance with the shipping registration regulations which I trust will not provide complications for those who will deal with them.

I take this opportunity to refer to the speech made in the House of Representatives by the honourable member for Hume, Mr Lusher, who is the Opposition's spokesman on transport matters. In the House of Representatives Hansard of 6 March 1984 from page 546 onwards Mr Lusher set out the Opposition's general position and discussed a number of matters including the shipping conferences and the need for competition. I can only say with my interest in industry and commerce, particularly in relation to Australian manufacturing industry, that nothing could be more important than ensuring that Australia is provided with time efficient and cost efficient shipping services for its imports and particularly for its exports. Growth in the manufacturing industry in this country will have to rely on exports. I believe that it is extremely important that we refer continually to the fact that the restoration of growth in the manufacturing industry will depend substantially upon the achievement of export opportunities. One thing that Australia has suffered from and suffered from severely is its reputation as an unreliable supplier. It is a reputation which we are now overcoming. We need to do everything we can to ensure that it is overcome in the long term. Therefore, steps which can be taken to make the shipping arrangements from Australia both cost and time efficient and competitive are to be applauded.

I do not wish to hold up the Senate by repeating the other comments which have already been made. I refer honourable senators to the speech made by Mr Lusher at the place to which I referred and indicate that the Opposition supports the passage through the Senate of both Bills and will not be moving any amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —As has been indicated by Senator Peter Rae, the Shipping Registration Amendment Bill 1984 and the Protection of the Sea (Shipping Levy) Amendment Bill 1984 are essentially procedural Bills. They are important to the Government's program in terms of its original policy intentions in this field. The intent of the Bills has been described by Senator Peter Rae. I do not want to go into any great detail about the Bills because I think the purpose of the Bills has been adequately placed on the record both in the House of Representatives and here. In any case, the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, Senator Gietzelt, will close the debate and make any appropriate technical comments about the legislation. All I want to say is that I think the Government's achievements in the maritime field since it took office in March 1983 have been quite considerable. This legislation meshes in with what we have done until now and continues that progress. The legislation that we are debating does not need to be reviewed in great detail. Because of the comments made by Senator Peter Rae, I do not think I need to make a long speech about it and I choose to leave my remarks there.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government thanks the Senate, particularly the Opposition, for its support of the Shipping Registration Amendment Bill 1984 and the Protection of the Sea ( Shipping Levy) Amendment Bill 1984 which are currently before the Senate. It accepts the fact that the legislation will be a step forward in assisting in the registration, control and efficiency of our maritime industry, particularly as it relates to shipping in general. I think it is gratifying that we have been able to reach a position where the Parliament, after due consideration by the States and the Northern Territory and through consultations that the Minister has had with the appropriate authorities, is able to pass these two pieces of legislation which the Government concedes are important to our maritime industry .

SPEECH.PARA: We accept that in the legislation we are not confronted with much controversy. Consequently, Senator Peter Rae was able to draw attention to some of the positive features, as well as some of the negative features, that were raised in debate in the other place. But it must surely be accepted and recognised that we are in these two pieces of legislation putting Australia in concert with the legislative requirements adopted by most other countries. We are a maritime country. We have a very large coastline and we therefore have a great number of ships capable of being registered. I am advised that we have 5,675 such ships in Australia. This covers, of course, not only commercial ships but also fishing vessels, yachts and government vessels.

The purpose of the legislation is to bring in a system of registration in accordance with the international standards and, in particular, in the second piece of legislation, to provide for a cost recovery system, so that in fact the registration system which is proposed will be at no cost, in due time, to the taxpayers generally. So in recording the details and recognition of the need to have an efficient and effective type of system for all ships that operate within our waters the Government has in its regulations of 1983 indicated that over the next five years sufficient funds will be collected as a result of an increase in the levy of 20 per cent so that we will reach a position at the end of a five- year period of a full cost recovery. I think that is in accordance with the basic principles of industries as far as is possible and practicable standing on their own feet. I do not think anyone can argue that we have seen a big development in our shipping industry in the post-war years. For example, we have 2,891 yachts. That is a development that we certainly would not have seen in the 1930s. We have seen that happen in the post-war years. Obviously this is an avenue that requires registration because we see from time to time these yachts not only use our coastal waters but often set out for longer journeys. It is essential that we have a registry system that provides for those journeys.

Senator Cook referred to the very impressive range of achievements that the Government has made in its first year of office in maritime transport generally. These include the ratification of a number of conventions and protocols, our activities on pollution and, of course, the ratification treaties dealing with the Safety of Life at Sea, known as SOLAS, and the establishment of a review system that will ultimately bring about a uniform shipping laws code throughout Australia. That has been the result of patient negotiation between the Federal Minister for Transport, Mr Morris, and his counterparts in all the States including the Northern Territory.

I think we are moving towards an effective system and a register that will play its part not only in providing citizens with some indication of the use of ships in our transport system but also with information because, as we know, there are occasions when the lack of such information and registration places at risk ships and personnel who hitherto have not been sufficiently aware of their obligations in respect of Commonwealth legislation. Clearly, it is a Commonwealth matter, a national matter, which this legislation seeks to redress.

I am thankful for the fact that the Senate is prepared to give its support to the Shipping Registration Amendment Bill 1984 as well as the complementary legislation, the Protection of the Sea (Shipping Levy) Amendment Bill 1984. The adoption of this legislation will, I believe, place the Government in a position to take control, not for control's sake but for the protection and efficiency of our maritime industry.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not wish to be taken as being churlish and I certainly do not wish this matter to take up further time but I take this opportunity to clarify something which may have been left in some doubt at the end of the speech of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt) closing the second reading debate. The original very comprehensive legislation was introduced during the term of the previous Government in 1981 to take effect from Australia Day 1982. The amendments which we are now making by the protection of the Sea (Shipping Levy) Amendment Bill, as well as the Shipping Registration Amendment Bill carry forward-I applaud the Government for carrying this forward-what was started by Ralph Hunt as the Minister for Transport at the time. I think he deserves to be recorded in the Hansard record of this debate as having played a very major part in getting us moving forward and I compliment the present Government for taking us still further forward.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer tonight to an incident which occurred in Canberra on the morning of 12 March this year. A tragic fire occurred at the Manuka Village shopping centre at about 10 to nine. A number of questions remain unanswered in the wake of this tragic fire.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a matter that ought to be referred to. I believe the people of Canberra are concerned about the number of questions and want to know the answers to them . In all, some 18 shops were destroyed. There was a death. One of the shopkeepers died on the footpath. It was suggested that he had had a heart attack while watching his own shop burn down. It is a tragic circumstance in that he left a widow and four young children.

It was fortunate that a police officer, Constable Hawthorn, was passing at the time, in a private capacity. He went into the shopping centre and assisted those inside to get out. It seems that the roof of the building collapsed within about 10 minutes of the fire having started. One cannot help but wonder what might have occurred and what a tragedy could have followed if the fire had been at, say, 11 o'clock on a Saturday morning when there were a lot of people in the centre.

One aspect of the matter that gives cause for concern and needs to be investigated is what has been reported to me as an electricity failure, or the electricity being turned off, which caused the automatic doors of the building to close and remain closed at that time, making exits difficult. I am told that there was only one other door through which people could get out. Obviously the actions of Constable Hawthorn assisted the few people who were in the building to get out before the roof collapsed, as I said, about 10 minutes after the fire started. There needs to be an inquiry as to whether that was the case, or what was the cause, in case anything of that nature should occur again.

Perhaps the greatest problem involved was that the biggest and best fire truck was not available to go to the fire. Since July 1982 Canberra has had a fire unit which cost $200,000. It has an 18-metre extension ladder with a very powerful hose which would have been able, had it been there, to pour water on to the roof of the building, which perhaps would have significantly cut down on the loss which occurred. I think that we are entitled to ask what steps the Government is taking to ensure that this unit is available if such a tragedy should occur again and what steps are being taken to ensure that the Australian Capital Territory Fire Brigade is as well prepared as it possibly can be for an incident of this nature.

There have been suggestions in the community that the water pressure available was not adequate. Stories abound as to what occurred about that. I guess the questions are: Was the water pressure adequate and, if not, why not; what steps are being taken to see that that is rectified or is capable of being rectified quite quickly? Again, if the water pressure was not adequate it would have been a problem for the new unit if it had been available. Originally when the fire unit came to Canberra it was suggested that there was some question about the vehicle's safety, although that is a little hard to believe. More recently we understand that the dispute was about the level of allowance to be paid for manning it. I believe we are entitled to say that this dispute must be resolved and that that unit must be available for the protection of buildings in this community, whatever age they might be.

This building was only about two years old. Apparently the fire spread very quickly after it commenced and, as I have said, within about 10 minutes the roof collapsed. If the fire had occurred at about 2 o'clock in the morning when no one was around one may not have wondered at how quickly it occurred. But at the hour of the morning when it did occur, with people about who saw the smoke quite quickly, it seems strange indeed that the fire should have commenced and burnt out in that short period.

It has been suggested that prior to the completion of the building the Australian Capital Territory Fire Brigade Commissioner made recommendations which were not complied with. I understand it is not being suggested that the building regulations themselves were not complied with, but perhaps it indicates that there needs to be a review of the building regulations to see that fire protection in a building such as this is quite adequate. One of the shopowners said to me: 'I was standing there crying. Part of me was going up with the building'. Many of those small shopkeepers lost a great deal more than will be covered by insurance. There is a suggestion that some of them were not adequately insured. That is a personal tragedy for them. But, even for those who had adequately insured themselves, a number of things which are lost in a fire cannot easily be replaced. There are not empty shops available in Canberra where they can go to set up business. It may well be that many of them will be out of business completely until this building is rebuilt and again available. That is a tragedy in personal and certainly in economic terms. There are some quite serious aspects of this fire which do need to be looked at most carefully. The community must be given an explanation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to pursue a matter that I raised in Question Time today that has been receiving considerable attention in the Press in Queensland in the last couple of weeks. It relates to the matter of redundancies created by Medicare. The treatment of former private health fund employees by the Health Insurance Commission is surely the most brutally cynical action yet by the Hawke Government. These unfortunate people took the Minister for Health, Dr Blewett, at his word last year when he said that he had provided that they be given preferential employment by the Health Insurance Commission under Medicare. Now he is giving them the brush-off. At the peak of the furore in mid-1983 over the Commonwealth Government's decision to make Medibank the sole agent for Medicare, the Minister for Health found it expedient to make promises which are now proving to be as hollow as any the Hawke Government has ever given.

SPEECH.PARA: In response to scores of letters that I received from private health fund employees I wrote to Dr Blewett last July asking him to reconsider certain parts of his policy. Mr President, in the interests of saving time, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the letter which shows in detail the points I made to Dr Blewett.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
13 July 1983
My Dear Minister,

I wish to make representations on behalf of employees of Private Health Insurance Companies concerning your Government's proposal to have Medibank act as the sole agent for the Medicare Health Scheme.
I respectfully ask you to consider the following points:

Your Government has stated that you do not wish to see redundancies created as a result of the introduction of Medicare. This appears to conflict with your statement that Medicare would operate with 1500 less employees. If this is so, a large number of private health fund employees will find themselves without jobs in the near future.

If Medicare begins staff recruitment in August 1983, staff currently employed in private health funds will be disadvantaged in applying for Medicare positions , since their current employers will require their services until Medicare begins in February 1984.
Is it possible that you may reconsider the position and allow private health funds to also act as agents for Medicare? A faster and improved customer service would be available.
With the growing concern in the Australian community for the problem of unemployment I sincerely request that you give consideration to those presently employed by private health funds.
I look forward to your response.
Yours sincerely, KATHY MARTIN Senator for Queensland The Hon. N. Blewett,
Minister for Health,
Parliament House,
Canberra, A.C.T. 2600

TALK.START.PARA: —In brief, I pointed out the conflict between his statements and those of the Hawke Government as a whole. The Government was claiming that it did not want redundancies. Dr Blewett was claiming that money would be saved by Medicare since 1,500 fewer employees would be required to administer health insurance. I also expressed concern that if the Health Insurance Commission recruited staff for Medicare as from August 1983 private health fund employees would be disadvantaged since the funds needed them until February 1984. The Minister made a lengthy reply. Again, Mr President, to save time I seek to have his reply incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
MINISTER FOR HEALTH Parliament House Canberra, A.C.T., 2600
Dear Senator Martin,
I refer to your personal representations of 13 July 1983 on behalf of employees of private health insurance funds concerning the use of the private funds in the administration of Medicare.

The decision by the Government to give Health Insurance Commission primary responsibility for the administration of Medicare was not taken lightly. It was the culmination of much detailed consideration and deliberation. In reaching the decision it did, the Government had regard to the fact that the Commission successfully administered the Medibank Scheme and being a national organisation administering Medibank Private, it has a wide network of branches and cash payments centres to provide an efficient service to the public. Although there will be some initial establishment costs, I believe that in the long term this arrangement will prove to be more economical than having a proliferation of agents.
The Government is, of course, concerned with the potential loss of employment by health fund employees and has taken the following action to alleviate the position:
* the Health Insurance Commission will be giving preference in employment to former health fund staff;

* in recognition of the particular problems faced by regional based health funds, which provide significant local employment, the Commission has offered agency arrangements to a number of funds covering certain regional centres in which they operate;
* State Health Ministers are being approached with the view to employment preference being given to redundant health fund staff, within their health care systems;

* discussions have been held with health funds on their future role under Medicare including the question of diversifying their activities into other areas to increase employment opportunities. Furthermore, among other things, the membership and range of activities of Medibank Private will be limited so that private health funds will have an assured role to perform.
These measures, combined with the normal turnover in fund staff, will minimise the net employment effect of Medicare.

The Government is taking special steps to deal with the period, between October 1983 to March 1984, when the Medicare system is gearing up and needing staff, and, at the same time, the private health funds will still be running at full capacity. Any employees taken on by the Health Insurance Commission during that period who are not former private health fund employees will be on contract. The basis of the contract will allow for former private health fund employees to take over these jobs in the Commission once Medicare assumes the bulk of current health insurance business. Accordingly, if people want to move out of the private health funds in February or March 1984, they will be able to do so and take up employment with the Commission.
Yours sincerely, Neal Blewett Minister for Health
Senator K. J. Martin,
Commonwealth Parliament Offices,
295 Ann Street

TALK.START.PARA: —In his reply, Dr Blewett stated:

SPEECH.PARA: the Health Insurance Commission will be giving preference in employment to former health fund staff;

He further stated that anyone employed by Medicare between October 1983 and March 1984, who was not a former private health fund employee, would be on a contract which would allow private health fund employees to take over those jobs this year. In part his letter stated:
Accordingly, if people want to move out of the private health funds in February or March 1984, they will be able to do so and take up employment with the Commission.

Now, in the face of growing retrenchments by private health funds-more than 100 last week in Queensland alone-Dr Blewett has done an about turn. A spokesman is reported by a newspaper in Queensland as saying that there was no guarantee that any of the workers would receive jobs with Medicare. If Dr Blewett's statement of August 1983 to me was not a guarantee what on earth was it? Dr Blewett may have changed his mind, but he cannot deny his own words, as he is attempting to do. Retrenched workers in Brisbane have been given a strong indication that they have virtually no prospect of being employed by the Health Insurance Commission. I understand that those who were retrenched were given a copy of the letter that Dr Blewett sent to me. Immediately I received the letter from Dr Blewett, I sent a copy to all the people who had written to me. Those people took copies of that letter to the Health Insurance Commission to show the undertakings which the Minister had given in that letter. They were met with complete indifference at the Health Insurance Commission office in Brisbane.

Dr Blewett's contracts for interim employees appear to have been a fiction. The interim appointees should have been told that their jobs were temporary. However , I am not aware that any of the retrenched private funds employees have been even interviewed, much less given any indication that they have any prospect of a job. The State Director of the Health Insurance Commission in Queensland is quoted as having said: 'We can't just sack our people'. I have sympathy for those people but the fact is that they should have been told when they were taken on that they were being given temporary jobs because the understanding the Minister had given to the employees of the health funds was that those jobs were to be on a contractual basis and were to be available come February or March. These people acted in good faith. They could have applied for Health Insurance Commission jobs last year but saw their then employers through to the end of the private funds' involvement in health insurance. They have learned that Dr Blewett's promises are not worth the paper they are written on. The Hawke Government's actions outside major cities have been particularly callous. Last August Dr Blewett said:

. . . in recognition of the particular problems faced by regional based health funds, which provide significant local employment, the Commission has offered agency arrangements to a number of funds covering certain regional centres in which they operate.

I wonder what happened to those agency arrangements? So far nearly 40 such employees have been retrenched in Queensland alone. In Cairns the only jobs offered by Medicare to private health fund people were part time jobs consisting of 10 hours work a week. Given Dr Blewett's track record on this subject alone, he should not be surprised if his undertakings on other subjects meet with great caution, if not outright rejection. Today I asked Senator Grimes, representing the Minister for Health, the following question:
How many employees has the Health Insurance Commission recruited from the private health funds since August 1983?
We must remember that he had said in his letter that any who applied from October on would be given preferential treatment. I also asked:
What is the total figure of additional Health Insurance Commission employees since August 1983?
Of course the difference ought to give us the number who should be on temporary contracts. The third question asked:
How many of the non-private health fund employees were recruited on a temporary contract basis and how many on a permanent basis?

There is every reason to expect that the difference between the numbers pertaining to the first two questions will not equal the number in the answer to the third question. Senator Grimes said he did not have the information but that he would have it by the end of the week. I would not have expected Senator Grimes to be able to give that information off the top of his head. I called his office at 9 o'clock this morning and said I was going to ask precisely these questions. I gave him notice, which is not unusual, because I hoped for an answer. Senator Grimes said he hoped to have the information by the end of the week.

There is no criticism at all of Senator Grimes or his staff in what I am saying , but what I do say is that these matters have been an issue for two weeks. I know the Minister for Health has been asked for those figures for some time. If he gave the Health Insurance Commission the direction that he indicated he would in his letter to me, then it should have been followed up and we should not be having the problems we have at the moment. It is possible that the direction has been followed to varying extents. In any event, I would have thought that by now the Minister for Health would have inquired of the Health Insurance Commission, if he believes it has that instruction, as to whether or not it followed it and what has been the employment rate of former employees of private health funds by the Health Insurance Commission. The statement by Mr Dickson that the Commission cannot sack its own people to make way for these retrenched people indicates to me that that policy was not pursued. Those figures should have been available. Had the Minister for Health been doing his job and cared about the situation, he would have got those figures some time ago. I suspect that the answer will not be a pleasant one.

I find intriguing the fact that apparently Dr Blewett's letter to me is the only publicly available piece of paper which sets out those statements. I did not provide it to anyone with the purpose of seeing it in the Press. The first I knew that it was in the possession of anyone other than those I had actually posted it to in response to their letters to me on the subject last year was when the Press contacted me and said that it had a copy of the letter. It is not a private and confidential letter; I suppose people were prepared to hand it around. Ever since then it has been a matter of some mystery to me as to why Dr Blewett's letter to me appears to be the only documentation to that effect. I do not believe I was the only Queensland senator who last year received scores of letters from residents of Queensland expressing concern about whether they would be retrenched as a consequence of Medicare. It is possible that individual members of the House of Representatives may have received no letters because they had nobody in that category in their electorates. But I cannot believe I was the only senator, and I find that particularly difficult to believe in view of the fact that I am an Opposition senator. People in the position we are discussing would write to the Opposition as a last resort. It is at least as likely that Government senators received as many letters as I did. I would like to know whether they wrote to Dr Blewett and expressed the concern of their constituencies. Government senators from Queensland ought to declare themselves on this and say whether they made representations and, if so, whether they got the same answer I got. If not, I would like to know why I received a different answer. If I did get the same answer, I would like to know why they are not doing something now about these employees.

So far the only Government member to show a flicker of interest has been the honourable member for Petrie, Mr Deane Wells, who rather unfortunately urged former employees of these funds to present themselves at the Health Insurance Commission; he was sure they would be taken care of. They have not been. They have been met with complete indifference. They have not been rudely treated but they have been cold-shouldered. Then they have rung me and told me about it because they had a piece of paper in their hands with my name on it. One woman who rang my office had more than 30 years experience with the private health funds, and there are others who have had several years experience. The simple fact is that some of the employees retrenched were specialists in processing health fund claims, a very technical area in itself. The funds no longer need specialists in health claims because they are not allowed to handle health insurance. Obviously they are the very people who are most vulnerable, regardless of their experience. Indeed, they are the ones who probably would have given themselves the best chance of getting a government job.

I look forward to the answer that Senator Grimes has undertaken to give. In the meantime, there are other questions to be answered, and pre-eminent amongst them is this: When Dr Blewett wrote that letter and gave those assurances, on which people acted in good faith last year, did he have any intention at all of making sure that the Health Insurance Commission carried them out?

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 24 August 1983:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 6 September 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is a Corporal A. J. Kingdom, who was wounded by a landmine in Vietnam in 1970 and who now has to wear calipers on both legs, not being granted the Defence Force Retirement Benefits invalidity pension to which he is entitled, if so, when will Corporal Kingdom receive the benefits to which he is entitled.
(2) Will the Government make an exgratia payment for the tax penalty he will suffer because of the mistakes and delays of the bureaucracy.
(3) Why has there been an unreasonable delay in correcting this obvious mistake .
(4) Will the Minister for Defence take appropriate action towards the authorities involved so that such delays do not occur in the future.

(5) Can the Minister give an assurance that the case of Mr Barry Roe, another Vietnam veteran in almost identical circumstances who was recently referred to the RDFWA, will not suffer the same bureaucratic shuffling and delay.
(6) Will the Minister investigate a system of proper legal advice and assistance for servicemen upon discharge so that such situations do not arise in future.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following revised answer to the honourable senator's questions:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Mr Kingdom was discharged on 31 August 1971 having completed his period of National Service. Under the DFRB legislation no invalidity benefit can be paid unless the member is medically discharged. Mr Kingdom brought his situation to the attention of the Army office in February 1983. Army Office has now informed the Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits Authority that at the time Mr Kingdom was discharged, grounds existed on which he could have been retired on the grounds of invalidity. This opens the way for the Authority to now consider the grant of an invalidity benefit and the level of benefit. The matter will be considered by the Authority as quickly as possible.

(2) Should Mr Kingdom qualify for an invalidity pension with considerable retrospectivity, my Department will examine the case for some form of compensation in recognition of any increase in the amount of tax payable by Mr Kingdom.

(3) The Army had no cause to review the ex-member's reason for discharge and the error remained dormant until brought to attention in February this year. Investigation involved several directorates in the Army and the office of the DFRDB Authority. Regrettably, the cumulative effect of their actions has contributed to the delay in processing Mr Kingdom's inquiry.
(4) Revised procedures have been implemented to ensure that such delays do not recur.

(5) Mr Barry Edward Roe was discharged from the Army on 21 April 1972, the reason supplied to the office of the DFRD Benefits Authority being 'AMR 176 (1) (A) having requested his discharge', and was advised on 23 May 1972 that he was entitled to a refund of contributions and a gratuity.
These entitlements were authorised for payment to him on the same date. No further correspondence or representations from or in relation to Mr Roe have been received.

(6) No. Discharge procedures are designed to ensure that the rights and interests of members are protected. The procedures include a review by a senior medical officer of the Final Medical Board findings. No change to discharge procedures is considered necessary.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Trade, upon notice, on 15 September 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Tasmanian iron ore pellet manufacturer, Savage River Mines, currently importing South African anthracite to be used in its iron ore pellet plant.
(2) Did one of South Africa's worst mine disasters occur on 12 September 1983 where 63 miners were killed in an underground explosion from methane gas in an anthracite mine.
(3) Do black coal miners receive 194 Rand per month in wages, which is 26 Rand below the South African poverty line.
(4) Does the Australian coal industry find it difficult to compete on economic grounds with South Africa, in the light of South Africa's lower labour costs.

(5) Is the Minister for Trade aware that on 14 September 1983, while visiting Australia, Mr Andrew Moletsane from the South African Congress of Trade Unions, urged Australia to ban South African anthracite on economic and moral grounds.

(6) Will the Government investigate the import of South African anthracite to Australia to determine: (a) its effect on the Australian coal industry; and (b) if this practice implies support for the South African apartheid system.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Trade has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's questions:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I refer the honourable senator to the reply given by the Minister for Resources and Energy in answer to Question No. 359 (Hansard, page 3815 of 14 December 1983).
(2) A disaster at the Hlobane Colliery in Natal on 12 September caused the death of 66 miners; 63 were killed underground and 3 died as a result of injuries.

(3) My Department has been informed that black underground workers in coal mines receive from 4 Rand per day-labourers-up to 20 Rand per day for a 26 day month based on experience, length of service, et cetera. In addition, single accommodation, food, clothing, medical and recreational facilities are provided. Operators of machinery, such as continuous cutters, are also entitled to a bonus of up to 150 Rand per month.

The average wage for black coal miners for the third quarter of 1983 was 303 Rand per month; this, in most cases, excludes accommodation and other benefits provided to miners. The national average wage for black workers is 319 Rand per month.
The household subsistence level for black workers, based on a family of six, varies between 264 Rand and 291 Rand depending on area.

(4) Ability to compete depends upon a wide range of cost and other factors, of which actual wage rates represent only one element. The totality of labour costs depends upon wage rates, manning levels and productivity. These vary markedly from mine to mine in both South Africa and Australia but lower South African wage rates are offset by higher Australian productivity.

South Africa is widely recognised as having the ability to quote some of the lowest prices in the international market, particularly for steaming coal, and South Africa is Australia's major competitor in a number of steaming coal markets. Buyers are, however, concerned with other factors, such as quality and long term reliability. Despite intense South African competition in recent times Australian coal exports in 1983 increased by more than 20 per cent with approximately half of the increase being steaming coal.

(5) During a visit to Australia in September 1983 as a representative of the African National Congress and the South African Congress of Trade Unions, Mr Moletsane met with officers of my Department. He said the purpose of his visit was to seek information on trade links between Australia and South Africa, but he did not raise with those officers the specific question of imports of South African anthracite by Savage River Mines.

(6) (a) I understand that Savage River Mines is currently actively investigating the suitability of Australian low volatile coals with a view to sourcing coal locally if it can meet technical requirements and be provided economically.
(b) The import of goods from South Africa does not imply Australian Government support for the South African apartheid system.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 14 December 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: Does the ANZUS Treaty still provide defence cover in countries that were under mandate to Australia and New Zealand when the Treaty was ratified, such as Western Samoa (New Zealand) and Papua New Guinea (Australia), now that such countries have achieved independence: if not, does the Government consider it advantageous to Australia's regional relations to advocate their inclusion in ANZUS.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The ANZUS Treaty applies to the metropolitan territory and the island territories under the jurisdiction of any of the three Treaty partners. It does not apply to former territories such as, in Australia's case, Papua New Guinea.

Australia does not have a defence treaty with Papua New Guinea and to date neither Government has put forward proposals for such a treaty. The nature of the defence relationship between Australia and Papua New Guinea is spelt out in the 1977 joint statement by Prime Ministers which affirms the intention of both Governments 'to consult', at the request of either, about matters affecting their common security interests and about other aspects of their defence relationship'. When he visited Papua New Guinea in June 1983 the Minister for Defence reaffirmed these arrangements on behalf of the present Government and assured Papua New Guinea that the Government saw a need for the two countries to maintain and develop the existing close defence relationship.

From my own contacts with South Pacific leaders, especially during the meeting of the South Pacific Forum in Canberra in August 1983, I am satisfied that Australian concern for the security and stability of all its South Pacific neighbours is well understood by these countries. Our concern has, moreover, been reflected in successive ANZUS Council communiques. The communique issued after the last ANZUS Council meeting, namely in Washington in July 1983 '. . noted that the security of the Pacific Island States is closely related to that of the ANZUS partners. In this context defence cooperation programs of the ANZUS partners are continuing to make a substantial practical contribution to regional security'.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs , upon notice, on 15 December 1983:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, upon notice, on 16 December 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Why did the Government not consult with the Northern Territory Government on the terms of reference for the land rights inquiry being conducted by Judge Toohey considering the resolution introduced in the House of Representatives on 8 December 1983 by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs regarding Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.

(2) Is the Government aware that this kind of unilateral action can only mean that efforts by the Northern Territory Government to improve relations between the Commonwealth and the Territory Governments will be further jeopardised.

(3) Does the Government intend to improve its performance with regard to consultation with Territory and State Governments; if not, will the Federal Government accept responsibility for any further breakdown in Commonwealth/ Territory/State relations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The terms of reference of the review by Mr Justice Toohey of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act did not go to the basic elements of the Act which were not at issue. They did, however, provide ample scope for attention to the administrative and procedural difficulties being experienced with the Act. They asked the Judge ''to make a general review'' of the Act and ''Recommend amendments to that Act and changes to any other legislation where appropriate'' having regard to the five principles which the Government sees as fundamental in relation to Aboriginal land rights; namely:
Aboriginal land to be held under inalienable freehold title;
protection of Aboriginal sites;
Aboriginal control in relation to mining on aboriginal land;
access to mining royalty equivalents;
compensation for lost land to be negotiated.

Following an approach to the Minister from the Northern Territory Chief Minister in July 1983, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs assured him that the terms of reference were cast very generally so that all detailed aspects of the legislation could be reviewed. There was no intention to limit the Northern Territory in bringing any problems it had encountered with the Act to the attention of the Judge.

In reply to an invitation from Mr Justice Toohey, the Northern Territory Government subsequently made detailed written and oral submissions on matters of concern to it. That Government was not disadvantaged in any way by the conduct of the review.

Further, the Australian Government will be consulting the Northern Territory Government, as well as other interested parties, in considering what action it will take in response to Mr Justice Toohey's report. Every reasonable effort will be made to accommodate the legitimate interests of the Northern Territory in this matter.

(2) and (3) I refute the implications inherent in these questions. The Australian Government will continue to consult with the Northern Territory Government on matters affecting the Northern Territory.

In addition staff were utilised in each office to walk along queues advising ratepayers of the location of cheque boxes and taking cheques from ratepayers who were willing to have a receipt sent out to them at a later date.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Trade, upon notice, on 29 February 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Have the United States of America and Australia signed an agreement under which Australia provides the United States with blanket permission for permitting the export of fuel containing Australian uranium.
(2) Was this agreement signed after the Labor Government came to office in March 1983.
(3) Does this agreement supersede the 1979 United States-Australia safeguards agreement which gave Australia the right of prior consent to exports by the United States to third parties.
(4) Does this new agreement cover only natural and low enriched United States fuel with Australian uranium; if so, what is the situation with any other types of fuel exports.
(5) What countries have received United States fuel containing Australian uranium.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Trade has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (2), (3) and (4) See my answer to Part (1) above.

(5) Australian uranium has been exported to the United States for use by several United States utilities for electricity generation, subject to the 1979 Agreement between Australia and the United States of America concerning peaceful uses of nuclear energy. The United States also offers toll-processing services to some countries with which Australia has agreements concerning nuclear safeguards. Consequently some of the Australian uranium exported for end-use in Japan and EURATOM has been converted and/or low-enriched in the United States- during which time it was subject to the Australia-United States Safeguards Agreement referred to above-before being retransferred to these partner countries for electricity generation. On a similar basis Australian uranium for end-use in the Republic of Korea is currently being converted, low-enriched, and /or fuel fabricated in the United States, with the intention that it be retransferred to the Republic of Korea for electricity generation in due course.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs , upon notice, on 28 February 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister for Foreign Affairs aware of recent trials of leaders of the Peace Association of Turkey.
(2) Have 23 citizens been imprisoned for pursuing the interest and the cause of peace in that country.
(3) Have some such citizens been sentenced to terms ranging between five and eight years for such activity.
(4) Will the Government protest to the Government of Turkey at this attempt to quash the non-violent peace movement in that country.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Government is aware that trials of leaders of the Peace Association of Turkey have taken place.
(2) The Government has received reports that 23 members of the Peace Association of Turkey have been imprisoned.
(3) Some of those imprisoned have received sentences ranging from five to eight years.

(4) The Australian Ambassador in Ankara was asked in February of this year to express to the Turkish authorities the concern that exists in Australia about the denial of human rights in Turkey, especially the denial of due process of law, torture and conviction on the grounds of political belief. The Ambassador has since made known our concern to the Turkish Acting President, the Prime Minister and to senior officials of the Turkish Foreign Ministry and has expressed our hopes that the newly elected Government's stated commitment to democracy will bring about a genuine improvement in the situation.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 29 February 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Federal Government intend Australia to remain a member of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation in the event of a United States pullout from that organisation.

(2) Is the Government satisfied that UNESCO is carrying out its charter in a proper and impartial manner; if not, will the Government seek to influence a change in the day-to-day functioning of UNESCO; if so, will the Government seek to influence the United States to maintain its membership and support of that body.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Australia does not intend to withdraw from UNESCO.

(2) The Government has expressed concern at some aspects of UNESCO's performance. These include the degree of politicisation of some debates, as well as certain inadequacies in the organisation's budget and administration which have detracted from its overall effectiveness. At the same time, Australia believes that UNESCO continues to play an important role in advancing international cooperation in the sciences, education, culture and communications . Such cooperation can benefit all member states, including Australia. The Government is therefore committed to playing an active role in seeking solutions to UNESCO's problems. It intends to work closely with fellow members from all geographical groupings to find practical ways in which improvements can be implemented.

The Government is naturally concerned that the United States has given notification of intention to withdraw from UNESCO at the end of 1984, although it understands the reasons for this step. Such action would deprive UNESCO of a substantial intellectual and practical input into its programs and would mean the loss of a quarter of its financial contributions. The Government hopes that conditions can be created in which the United States may be able to reconsider its decision to withdraw. For its part, the Government will work actively to this end.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 7 March 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister for Primary Industry aware of the report of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works relating to the Australian Wheat Board accommodation at Ceres House, Melbourne, for Head Office and Victorian Branch.
(2) Are the Australian Wheat Board's activities in relation to:
(a) operations on the domestic and international money markets to fund the crop acquired from growers and to invest temporary surplus funds; and
(b) operations on the wheat and financial futures markets, in accordance with the provisions of its statutory powers?

(3) What are the details of the accommodation requirements that 'the accommodation should be of a standard appropriate to receive, negotiate with, and provide hospitality to delegations and visitors and to reflect Australia's position as a significant wheat trading nation'.
(4) Why are 25 car parking spaces needed 'to provide discreet access for sensitive visiting delegations'.
(5) Did the Wheat Board consider restructuring its staff and functions rather than Ceres House.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.
(2) (a) and (b) Yes, so far as I am aware.
(3) and (4) Details of the accommodation, including materials and finishes, were provided as Appendix 1 of the report referred to in Question (1).

The above report found that car parking within the premises was an important requirement both for AWB efficiency and for visiting delegations. In other words , the 25 spaces are required not solely for visiting delegations, but for the AWB's general needs.
I should add that I have been kept fully informed by the Australian Wheat Board of its proposal to redevelop Ceres House.

I have accepted the advice of the AWB that it requires additional and improved accommodation and that the redevelopment of Ceres House is the best of a number of options considered. I note that this view has been endorsed by the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works following its public enquiry into the proposal.

(5) The functions of the Australian Wheat Board are currently under complete re -examination because the wheat marketing and pricing arrangements expire on 30 September 1984. These functions were included in the open and wide ranging enquiry into the wheat industry by the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC).

The IAC's report has been considered by myself and my State counterparts at the Australian Agricultural Council (AAC). The AAC has recommended only slight variations in the AWB's marketing and pricing functions for the next five year period. The Commonwealth Government has yet to take final decisions on the IAC's report and the AAC recommendations.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Kilgariff, in the adjournment debate of 28 February 1984 (Hansard page 64), raised the matter of an article which appeared in the Northern Territory News of 8 February 1984 concerning interim upgrading at Darwin Airport.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Aviation has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

My Department is currently examining the possibility of providing some minor upgrading within the international arrivals area of the Darwin Airport as an interim measure pending the construction of the new terminal building.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 2 December 1983 (Hansard, page 3232), Senator Robert Ray asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Aviation, a question without notice which sought the reasons for a $34m loss by Qantas Airways Ltd in the last financial year, and asked what steps Qantas proposed to take to rectify this matter.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Aviation (Mr Beazley) has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's questions:
Qantas has advised in relation to the particular questions:

The loss by Qantas Airways Ltd in 1982-83 of $34m was caused by a deterioration in the international aviation environment which in turn was due to the world wide economic recession. Although the Company's costs were pruned to the extent realistically possible, the cost increases recorded nevertheless exceeded revenue growth. This was reflected in the reduction in the Company's revenue load factor, that is, the percentage of total aircraft capacity actually utilised by paying passengers, mail and freight forwarders, from 62.7 per cent in 1981-82 to 59.5 per cent in 1982-83. Many costs however are outside the control of the Company; for example, the increase in Qantas' fuel costs in 1982- 83 was $44m.

Improvements have already been achieved in the Company's profitability during 1983-84, with increased revenue earning initiatives taken, and lower staff costs resulting from staff separations arranged in 1982-83.
